review_title: Some Reasons I Will Not Leave Nokia Very Soon
pros:
1. I feel proud to be associated with Nokia due to its utility to the world we live in, powerful nostalgic brand, long history of reinventing itself, Bell Labs' Nobel Prizes, big clients and advancement in 5G technologies and IoT.

2. I do not have to put up with micro-management. I feel trusted to get my job well done and recognized as an expert. 

3. I feel comfortable to express my opinions (often critical but in good faith) in front of direct/senior management. I have the chance to influence and receive consistent autonomy and support to take initiative to use available resources in improving HR for the better.

4. I see my career growing in this company. On a daily basis, I have the chance to continuously learn about both telecom industry and Talent Acquisition, collaborate with people from all over the world etc.

5. I enjoy a solid compensation& benefits package, great office facilities (gym, sauna etc..), a flexible schedule, possibility to join the employee share plan  etc.
cons:
1.  Similar to other companies on the market, HR professionals represent “the rules". We are often seen as technocrats or policy wonks by both line managers and employees. 

2. There is no solid learning& development program to improve the business acumen of the HR community.

3. Fast-changing challenging environment and high work volumes in the Talent Acquisition team. Not easy to adapt if you prefer stability and a slower rhythm.

review_title: Re-organizing too often causes the company to not fully realize the advantages of each change in structure
pros: Nokia is very good at life balance and seems to support the overall welfare of the employees. Salaries are beginning to fall inline with the rest of the companies in the industry. Management is very good at  listening and to the ideas and thoughts of its employees and in most cases those suggestions are taken into account if possible. Nokia has also been as helpful as possible finding jobs for  employees that are impacted by cost savings measures or by other actions causing a reduction in force. For the Most part Nokia is thoughtful for the individual and while their decisions are not always best for the employee, they do try to reduce the impact.
cons:
Great place to work in the late 90's and early 00's but seems to have lost its way in the face of heavier competition. 
Their have r been numerous re-org's in the past 5 years but have accomplished little in the way of improveing management and making the company more flexible to threats and opportunities in the industry. Nokia tends to knee jerk when it comes to re-orgs by releaseing employees that have a  wealth of experience and knowledge, Rather than finding roles for these affected employees they release them and move their roles to other countries where less experience and less salary burden can be realized. Eventually this will catch up to them.

job_title: Senior Portfolio Manager in Bristol, England
pros:
Nokia tries to do the right thing, and live by it's values of Respect, Achievement, Renewal & Challenge. It has a strong ethics & environmental policies that all employees & suppliers must follow. Compensation & benefits are good, and high performance is recognised. 

As a large company that is present in nearly every country there are many opportunities to advance careers internally, and the variety of roles available is wide. while not cutting edge in terms of technology use, and immature in use of best practices like Agile development, lean sigma six etc there is a good focus on execution and quality.

If you put the time in it can be easy to build your own internal network, and generally other employees are supportive, and welcoming.
cons:
As with any large multinational it can be a very frustrating environment with projects often answering to multiple managers which slows progress down.

Decision making takes way too long, often due to the number of steering boards and stakeholders involved

Internal politics are reducing, but very slowly 

Commitment to change to become a leader rather than a follower is only on paper, not in reality. For a company that has consistently changed it's focus over the last 150yr it now seems to be afraid of transformation

Shareholders are still the most important party, not customers or employees.

Many middle managers are poor with no training, or guidance once they get promoted. Results in many great teams led by weak mangers

review_title: One good place to start working, but still...
pros: Advantages of being an Intern in IT Strategy & Developlment where I've been, is for sure being able to see how an IT department really works. You're at first treated like an intern, that is they'll teach you everything and they'll enourage you to ask questions - if you don't do, then it's not an overall good impression. But then, it is their interest that you grow professionally there, this means that after a couple of months they expect you to behave like a normal full-time employee - even though of course your wage might not increase in 6-7 months. But it really depends on which team you join; I've been gifted by joining a committed team and one of the best managers of the whole IT department in NSN (6.000 thousands people, 10% of the company), but my friends in other teams didn't have the same impression by their own teams.
cons: Surely Nokia Siemens Neworks is not passing a nice time now; there's a lot of demotivation in the employee, so if I were given an opportunity to work there right now, I would reject (of course if I'll have other opportounities to choose from...). Surely I don't have the impression now that with NSN I'll have a long-term job, given the current situation chrysis and the fierce competition in the Telco market by Huawei and Ericsson.

review_title: Good place to invest career capital
pros: Nokia is very employee-focused. Excellent benefits such as a strong employee training program that is continuously adding the newest resources have made it a good place to invest my career capital. The company takes diversity and ethics seriously in my experience.  Work-life balance is good - when you're at work, you work hard, but you get to use your ample vacation benefits. Some companies talk about work-life balance but create a judgmental atmosphere around using vacation. Nokia isn't like that. It recognizes that you drive yourself hard when you're at work and that kind of effort requires some down-time in the form of paid time off. Senior leadership has high expectations, as it should, but it also seems sympathetic to employees and wants to see us develop and be successful.
cons: The telecom industry is undergoing challenging times, and this has impacted Nokia, Ericsson, Cisco, Huawei and many other companies. Staffing can be tight on some projects. But in my experience, managers try to prioritize rather than engage in death marches. In my area, it's common for some overtime to be required, but that's true in the industry as a whole.

review_title: Great place to work and grow.
pros:
This Business Unit offers great opportunities to grow and advance within the organization.  They do recognize a work/life balance and encourage employees to shut down from work and enjoy your life.  Management encouraged eduction in both professional areas and in personal interest.  Once you were in a career path, you weren't forced to stay there.  Anyone could decide to expand themselves thru a career change.

Senior Management had an open door policy.  This wasn't lip service, you really could just drop by and speak with the General Manager of the Unit.  How often can you say that about a place you worked?
cons:
When people hear the name Nokia, they first think of cell phones or mobility.  Few know that Nokia has the most secure Firewall and provide other products such as Intrusion Prevention Systems.  Name branding was strong on mobility and very weak on Network Security.  

Everything had to be decussed to death.  The Finnish model of Management enforced the practice of agreement.  Sometimes, it is very hard to obtain and even harder when personalities or egos get in the way.  On occassion, it would have been good to take action and then work thru the committee.  

These are the only two things I can think of as negatives.

job_title: Solutions Architect in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros: none at all. Cannot understand why anyone would take a job with Nokia especially in a European country
cons:
I was part of comptel and with dread read the email saying that comptel would be bought by Nokia in 2017. During the acquisition the Nokia management said that even though many of us at comptel used to work for Nokia / NSN that things were different now and we would be valued and thrive as a standalone business in Nokia. 
That changed even before the acquisition was completed and Comptel disappeared and we soon realised things were as before. Endless tools and processes to be followed. Nobody to really talk to, just a tool to use. I looked around for another job and was so happy to leave. The same week I resigned they announced a round of job cuts which is an annual affair (there was another round in Jan 2020). I feel sorry for my ex-colleagues (those who are left anyway since they leave on a regular basis). I also feel sorry for Finns in general since Nokia was once a flagship company recognised around the world and something to be proud of.  Now they just want to get rid of as many people and save as much money as possible. I'm so glad to work for a competitor of theirs and clap with joy for every customer we take away from Nokia.

Exciting product. Nokia's reach means you have a chance to shape the future of the mobile/internet industries. 

The shear size of the organisation means there are plenty of opportunities to move around and experience different roles/businesses. 

I detected very little poltics and back biting where I was, although I get the impression things may be different in product development.

Genuinely forward thinking organisation, continually looking to reinvent itself and move tthe market in new directions.. 

Aspirations to rival Google in the search/advertising market.

Excellent work/life balance. Working from home/flexitime not a problem. Good, fairly well priced food. Nice offices.
cons:
Good at churning out fairly dull handsets in huge numbers, not so much at genuine innovation these days. The huge success of the iPhone has taken chunks out of the N-series cash cow. This may be changing, too soon to tell however.

Decision making is by committee - takes a while to get things done.

Not as agile as some of it's smaller rivals (as could be expected). Some new strategies (Ovi, N-gage) perhaps overly ambitious, and show signs of being dropped after massive investment. Time will tell I guess.

Laid back management style is generaly a plus, although I get the feeling those who sit back will probably get away with it.

Salaries are merely average (Nokia don't want people in it for the money).

review_title:
Local Management Finally Succeed in Delivering Spectacular Failure. 
Job losses - R&D closure - No surprise!
pros:
Experience in a multinational, hi tech engineering company. 
Working with a good mix of international people. 
Experience in a rapidly expanding and exciting industry sector.
Good professional experience can be gained quickly due to the short product cycle times.
English widely spoken alongside Danish, Finnish etc
Flexible working conditions.
Good canteen.
Good location by the waterfront.
Good building design.
Good fitness facilities.
cons:
"Country Club Institution" atmosphere - e.g. employees more interested in canteen goodies than job.
Very few people working after 4.30pm - demotivational, far from inspirational.

Local High Level Management - "Nepotistic" "Coat-tailors", widely seen as first to new opportunities. The first to jump ship when seas are stormy! Typical insular small country type mentality. Not generally reflective of Nokia.

Maybe it seems harsh, but hardly surprising for a small-country European multinational which has become an ancient dianosaur (i.e. out of touch, oversized and slow), and which now finds itself on the edge of extinction.
Dishonest self serving middle management.

Politically based and inconsistent investment rationale e.g. travel / hiring etc. Depends on having the right connections, not what one can do for Nokia.

pros: Competitive salary and benefits. Some teams are ok with working remotely.
cons: This is a company that conquered the world and then lost everything. That pain is still there, particularly given the extremely poor senior management and bad decision making. Of the 3 current businesses (Networks, HERE and Technologies), I would bet only Networks will remain in 2-3 years. If that is your goal, then please do join the company. If not, avoid it. Your career will not advance at all. HERE will be sold and Technologies has a very questionable executive team. Technologies has people with a terrible track record in launching products (collecting failure after failure... Meego anyone?) heading an entire Products business unit... which is supposed to launch new Nokia products soon. It also shows another problem with the company: you don't get promoted by your work, but by who you know. It is a shame - this was an incredible place to work for, lots of fun and great team spirit. However, with constant layoffs, with great talent leaving and with poor managers being promoted, this became a terrible company. If you are about to retire and/or don't mind spending a few years not doing much, getting a good salary and not advancing your career, then maybe this is the place for you. If not, avoid it.

review_title: NSN has lots of opportunity...for improvement
pros: Vacation on par with Europe, opportunities to work on projects outside the US.  The majority of co-workers and lower level managers are quite bright and competent.  The product portfolio is broad and seems to be accepted outside of the US marketplace.
cons: NSN is organized in silos, but run as a matrix organization.  To accomplish something as simple as a quote for an existing product requires configuration management from one team, pricing from another, project management from a third.  The layoffs from post merger consolidation were very de-motivating to much of the workforce, and due to the inability to accomplish our goals, we've seen very high attrition as well.  Since we're not replacing the people who move to other companies, the workload for those who remain continues to increase.  Plus we're loosing the brightest, most innovative people and keeping those who are comfortable with the status quo.

review_title: My experience seems to be different from many - perhaps because I'm in the UK?
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in London, England
pros:
Although the workload can be heavy, the general atmosphere is quite relaxed.

There is some good technology in use, and if you start working here after being with smaller companies you will learn a lot.

There are many intelligent and experienced colleagues, who are great for providing all kinds of information.
cons:
Cons – In my time at Nokia, there have been multiple re-organisations and shifts in strategy and focus, many of them failures, in particular the last one. This was supposed to stop the silo mentality which was so prevalent; instead it's had exactly the opposite effect.

There are serious doubts amongst the employees about the Windows Phone strategy that Nokia has adopted, while throwing out almost everything else. It's make or break time for Nokia.

General morale is really, really low due to repeated and heavy layoffs.

It's a hugely finno-centric company; if you work in other countries, even in Europe, you seem to be more of an afterthought than a full member of staff. This is evidenced in company communications and in the general attitude of a surprisingly high number of employees.

review_title: Nice place to work, decent salary, good team spirit
pros: I always have been happy with the amount of experts you can work with here. Information is freely exchanged and when you are asking a qualified question from someone, you will get good responses. Overtime is not encouraged and it is easy to adjust work and spare time. E.g. work a Saturday and then take a Friday off. Salary is industry-average. Company car policy is a bit weird (depending on CO2 exhausta leasing car is paid for between 25-50%). I would not consider it as a good benefit. Yearly bonuses are not too good as company is currently in rough times, but something in the area of 3-5% is always there. In good years it's 10-15%.
cons:
Sometimes HR saves money in the wrong places, e.g. stop renting in-door parking places. Due to current rough times business trips are rather rare. So if that's something you're after, you definitely need to go for some customer-facing job. 

For some constant restructuring (and layoffs) might look scary, but you learn to ignore them after staying in the company for many years. It affects people, but if you're an expert and not exactly in an area that is not really needed anymore, you'll survive.

pros:
Nokia Networks has a lot of high-caliber professionals globally. They work in a highly competitive truly global market. Each country has only 2-5 potential customers (telecom operators) and the deals with them are very large. This makes working at Nokia Networks very exciting.
- It's easy to gain additional responsibility
- There are plenty of opportunities to move across countries
- People do what they promise and there is a culture of helping colleagues
- Customers are large and the culture is customer-centric
- Very professional and active internal communications
- Management is well approachable and wants to listen to employee feedback
- Very flexible for remote working
cons:
I believe the cons were a bigger issue earlier and have meanwhile improved clearly:
- The company operates in an extremely competitive market, which puts continuous pressure on margins. This has meant a lot of restructurings since Nokia Siemens Networks was formed in 2007. During recent years the situation has improved. 
- There also used to be quite a lot of politics involved, like there often is in this large companies. I believe that has also improved meanwhile.
- The organization structure used to be very matrix oriented. This made it sometimes difficult to get fast decisions that also get implemented. I believe there has also been improvement in this area.

review_title: Nokia mobile devices, smart devices and its great working culture no longer exists
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros:
Nokia mobile used to be a great company, great culture, value for individual and collective thinking. Allows challenge to top management. 
Microsoft is a great company too, a very different culture however to Nokia, more value to individualism, not very enthusiastic about challenging status quo, but full with talented people.
cons: Unfortunately, the marriage (acquisition) of Nokia has taken the worst of both cultures, top quality people from Nokia has left the building, all the top managers (old guard) responsible of the failure of Nokia strategy an execution stayed, Microsoft could not differentiate who was staying, but the had to keep the top management to administrate the acquired unit, as a result, the top management (old one) that stayed, is keeping all its vicious and lack of leadership and business acumen, and in the process of "restructuring" this so called top management, and direct reports, are only keeping their unconditional people on board, sadly, not the most talented people again, but the experts in politics and hand-kissing are staying... results of this will be seen soon

review_title: Company in Athens does not want to focus on real problems

pros:
- Flexible working hours (depending on the LM)
- Possibility to work from home (depending on the LM)
- Payroll is never late
cons:
- Company re-hires employees that left the company few months ago with high salaries while gives 1-2% raise to current employees and high performers. It is suggested that you leave Nokia & come back after 6-8 months. Only then you will get higher salary and respect.
- There is no reward of any kind - it is pointless to go the extra mile or support the company beyond your job description
- There are many unsuitable Line Managers doing damage to peoples/teams. There is no poor performer plan for them - They will be LMs until retirement. 
- Upper management is not in place to take actions to fix real issues. Problems are know but trying to hide them under the carpet.

review_title: Everything is not what it seems
pros:
Interesting technology, good work-life balance, great starting salary + free cell phone + cafeteria, friendly workplace.
There are some very talented seniors to learn from.
cons:
It seems like that the only thing that matters is that how long have you been in the company, not your overall performace.
If you are relatively new at the company (1-2 years), no matter how great do you perform, forget about salary increase or better position for several years... You will be handled the same as the laziest newcomers...

An other thing is I personally feel that most of the developers looks down on software testers because they are "just testers". When testers warn them about possible errors, they don't care, but when customers notices that same errors, they often points their fingers at us, that we've should find these errors...

We have processes, but often we don't follow them, "quality first" aspect has gone...
Because the company does not have any pursuit to keep the good performers, they often leave after 1-2 years, and then they start a mass-hiring period, when a lot of newcomers join, and then the good ones will leave again, and it goes on and on in a loop...
Management seems like to only care about headcount, not overall performance.

pros:
Work Culture is great. People support each other very well. The senior management encourages openness and camaraderie within the teams.
Brand: The fifth most vauable barnd is still a benchmark in terms of organization and processes within. You get recognized outside well if you are from Nokia.
Flexibility: Easy work times, one can manage his personal and professional life well in Nokia.
Learnings: Great place to learn. It has a history of successes and each can be a worthy case study.
Opportunities to advance career: Performers are rewarded well in terms of career path and movement upwards in the organization or in geographies.
cons:
Salary: The salary is a pity. Pathetic to put it the other way. The slaries drawn in Nokia an x level = salaries drawn in competing companies in x-2 levels.
No transparency in remmuneration (a junior employee can earn more than a mid senior manager): A management trainee can earn more than a 4 years old professional in the company. Not exactly seet for the mid level manager.
Company culture is risk averse: Nokia has goofed up in its foray into internet services. It still is investing but the organization is too huge to learn new tricks and accomodate change.

pros:
Nokia has recovered its years of bad performance with a simple rule: standardize, control and move to India. This helped a lot to recover the situation and now Nokia is an healthy company, investing to grow again in its business.
If you want an experience in a really global organization, where you'll work with people around the world seamlessly, and you have technical TLC expertise, Nokia can be an interesting place to work.
cons:
This obsession for control it's frustrating for me, and I believe it's draining the vitality from people. I don't see happiness around me, just people resigned that this is life and I've to accept it. 
Managers remember to people to smile and say hello to colleagues, is this something that needs to be reminded? Most of the time I smile when I meet a colleague and in some cases I'm asked "Why are you smiling?". Nokia it's a company made of androids, starting from the CEO who is not meeting people, just sending few messages during the year via e-mail or a video saying how we have to behave. Is he a real person?
Moreover, Nokia is a company that is shrinking year over year by 10% on average.
One thing I believe really embodies the Nokia culture: the policy defining responsibilities in the sales process is called "Limitation" of Authority.

pros: The company is the home of Bell Labs.  There are a lot of very smart people here.  There is a lot of freedom to be creative. You can find an expert on virtually any topic here.  This is very powerful for moving forward in your career.  This is a great place to learn and grow.
cons: The company has gone through over a decade of generally negative financial results.  It merged with Alcatel, and now has been acquired by Nokia.  The impact on employees is the looming concern of losing your job. There have been layoffs every year or so.  Also the financial instability has caused a negative negative impact on salaries and raises.  If you are hired in, you can probably negotiate a good salary, but do not count on big increases once you are in.

review_title: Nokia, not what it once was
pros: Global reach, large still somewhat positive brand recognition OUTSIDE of the US.
cons: Prior to the current CEO, the modus operandi was, "when in doubt, reorganize".  There were 6 or 7 major reorganizations within the 5 years I've been at Nokia. Now, they're brining in outside talent who, despite the company laying off literally thousands worldwide, are hiring from outside for jobs that could have been easily handled by internal employees.  They are admittedly extremely generous in the current round of layoff packages, but the new leadership team are spotty in terms of expertise relevant to their current executive roles.  And they have a global company transfer policy of moving just your stuff with no regard to cost of living increases, return policies, housing and child education support...just moving you and your stuff like a pawn on a chessboard.  Great, talented staffers are at times refusing to move for the company these days given the constant (and I mean at least over the last two years and continuing) turmoil and bad company financial results.  Morale low too.  Think twice about joining, and if there, refurbish your LinkedIn and CV materials and start networking broadly outside.

pros: The company and colleagues were nice.
cons: None. My period there was fine

review_title: Old dusty brand trying to find a way back on top
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Good work environment and good engineers at the company. A great organization for developing international experience. Lots of good training opportunities. Plenty of interesting new product ideas to work on.
cons: The leadership at Nokia is weak and decision making is nearly impossible for the organization. In addition, the company is still living in the days when it was the top handset mfg. The arrogance that often permeates an organization that is the market leader is still strong at Nokia. Their market share is eroding making success in the all-important smartphone space more difficult. The Nokia brand in the most important market is not even considered. How many people in your network own a Nokia phone? With losses in the 1st Qtr. of 2012 more cost cutting is in the future for this company. If you are interested in working for a mobile handset mfg., this is not the one to join.

pros: Core Technology and focus on the SP (Telco) market and adjacent IP related markets. Nokia as a mobile operator is compelling, focused to deliver on the promise for their top 40 global customers. This BU, though extremely process orientated, has a recipe that works. Caution the entrepreneur .
cons:
Unfortunately, anything outside of mobile is riddled by x Alcatel and Nortel people in middle to top management roles. The Company tries to recruit new blood but after3 years most have left due to the poor cliquey technical sales management, who frankly do not have a clue. They know how to manage up but not run business and engage the field facing sales staff. Nokia appears to have a strategy to eliminate any job in western, Northern Europe and move it to India or Hungary. So you work with a virtual team in a different TZ than do not understand well the local language customs, customers. The company will survive as there is not much competition left and mistakenly the EU thinks Nokia is still European but that boat left with most staff now in India or USA.
Nokia is not for the change agent, make a difference type of person.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Nokia is a HUGE company, so it is critical to understand where you're going (will you be a part of Business Unit, Regional staff, Admin function that reports to Finland, etc.). Your experience will vary a Lot depending on where you work. I'm only familiar with a part of Nokia that develops networking equipment. The culture of this group is very different from the rest of the company. The group originally was formed by f-Alcatel purchase of a Silicon Valley start-up, so many people has done one+ start-ups and consequently the culture reflects it.
cons: It's important to read Pros. Cons - you are a part of a very large company. If you're a superstar, it might not hurt you, but if you're "just a great above expectations employee", you might face with the fact that in order to increase xxx (whatever you want to increase), you'll have to look elsewhere. The pros - your paycheck comes regularly. The cons - it is hard to get anything special related to compensation because if your business/your role is doing great, there is certainly another business within such large company that is doing poorly. No stock (technically there is stock, but ... $5-stock with no stock grants is the same as "no stock)

review_title: Not the best time to join Nokia
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros: Good environmental policies (e.g. you can expense carbon offsetting for business trips), treats employees like people rather than resources, 25 days' holiday, flexitime (to be agreed with line manager), friendly and considerate colleagues, opportunities to travel to Finland (if you're lucky - there is a travel ban) which is a beautiful country full of lovely people. Some (though not all) offices have excellent subsidised staff canteens. New CEO will hopefully turn things around and make Nokia a more software-focused company.
cons: Huge company brings with it an inevitable level of bureaucracy. Many layers between the CEO and the average engineer mean it is hard to feel engaged with company strategy etc. Frequent re-organisations leading to people not really taking responsibility for things and not ever having to eat their own dogfood. Questionable tools & processes. Losing market share. Just announced big redundancies. Employee morale amongst the engineers is pretty low at the moment. "Not invented in Finland" syndrome - an idea has to have a Finnish name against it to get anywhere.

job_title: Senior Software Design Engineer in Nokia
pros: Was a great place to work during the mobile phone boom.  The salary was probably on the lower end of the range but the benefits were good, the time off was great (since it was a European company), and the opportunity to travel was good.  Lots of opportunity to work with smart people from all over the work and make world class products.
cons: Suffered from big company complacency and suffered greatly from it.  With the thinking they were invincible in the mobile phone industry they ignored the industry trends and the insight of their employees and decided things like flip phones, touch screen phones, app ecosystem, and US market were not important.  Eventually these missteps caused the failure of the mobile phone business and eventual sell off to Microsoft (which was a brilliant move by Nokia to cash out but a horrible move for Microsoft and all of the employees that were eventually let go).

pros:
1. Flexibility of working hours(sometimes depends on manager)
2. Work from home option (very good for ladies)
3. Most of the managers(barring a few) have technical background, so its easier to express the issues and roadblocks.
4. If you really want to learn, you will learn a lot of things.
5. No team leads to boss over you. Scrum masters are only restricted to facilitate team members and nothing more or less.
6. Easy to route between different different business lines - core platforms, LTE, small cells, femto, Operations & Management.you name it
7. Open for innovative ideas
8. Food and transport is very reasonable compared to other companies in Bangalore.
9. Offers 7:30pm cabs for those who stay late.
10. Checks on women employees who leave office late until they acknowledge they reached home.
cons:
1. Company has gone through lot of reorganizing from Nokia Siemens Networks to Nokia Solutions and Networks to Nokia Networks to now Nokia. So frequent reshuffling was common in 2013-1014
2. Due to losses incurred, perks were removed in 2012-2014, but now again its all looking good.
3. Weekend work needed sometimes during critical releases.
4. They are experimenting a lot with processes so some frequent changes in process could be a bit disappointing for employees.

review_title: Good Company overall but needs improvement
pros: A big mix of people and culture. Diverse and has open doors.
cons:
Career paths can be a challenge. Technical track career path is not suitable to keep the people where they can thrive. Most technical experts aim to go to sales or management positions to get to higher levels and rewards.

Second is that the company is divided into several business groups. Each looks for their own benefit and not Nokia. Lead Business group function does not work and internal system of revenue sharing between business groups should be reviewed.

Post sales in Nokia is very fragmented. No clear ownership towards customers and even internally. Partially due to the Business groups divisions and partially to not being able to have "active and empowered" lead functional role for all post sales responsible for each particular customer.

review_title: It was used to be a good place to work 5-6 years ago. Not anymore, and it is time to wake up before it is too late...
pros:
It was a very good place to grow your professionalism by working globally. 
In the past, management was very supportive for individual growth. 
I would say it was the best employer for me (1 out of 3).
Respect towards individual.
cons:
Very poor management nowadays. It's just one way communication.
Employees are not seen as an asset. It is hardly seen that management is willing to invest on its own people nowadays.
Poor (R&D) product quality control & product development management.
Slow to react on the market/competition.
Sometime, simple thing can be very complicated. Too bureaucratic.
Too many managers, and less staffs who are really doing the real jobs.
Out of scope job delegation coming from the top.

review_title: Post-merger - some ways better, some ways not
job_title: Senior Technical Consultant in Richardson, TX
pros: Still allowing telecommuting. Hands off approach of the best of Alcatel-Lucent, allowing the profitable parts to run independently. Removed Franco-based management from continuing to make poor decisions. Strong middle-management support allowing local areas to support their projects. Much better than the Chinese players in this space.
cons: Although still allowing telecommuting, the merged company does not really understand the needs of telecommuters. IT is a joke, it is outsources to DXC (formerly HPE). I swear they use them to force employees to learn as much as possible to support their own IT infrastructure needs. Although no longer French, the Euro mentality still reigns at C level management and down to upper management. They really should learn some lessons from the best of the Americas and Asia.  Always focusing on lowest cost at the expense of value to both the company and customers.

pros: Home Office, Flexible working time
cons: Inhuman treatment of staff, Poor culture

review_title: Great values and people. Average leadership and motivation of great people.
pros:
Open culture and lot of freedom to contribute and affect to topics. Great colleagues to work with

You can have homeoffice connection and work also from home. Good occupational health care. Good possibility for promotions if you have good relationship to your manager and you have exceed limits of objectives/targets.
cons:
Very limited resources because of cost reductions. Lot of job terminations and outsourcing.
 
Bonuses are good if you get one. Previously (2013) bonus was based on company performance and if company makes loss, you do not get any bonus. -> this is not very motivating even if you have exceed your personal goals and got personally exceptional performance rating.

Persons need to be concious about own time management working in a very hectic environment. You can easily work 24/7. Some leaders make some of the decisions based on feeling and current discussion, not so much based on analysis.

pros: On the upside I would put the relative freedom that you have in selecting the projects you would like to work on, and the approach that you will follow in tackling them. Also there is a good level of respect and humility in the work place. People are kind and helpful.
cons:
- Management is basically comprised of ex-researches, with poor management skills. 
 - Although there is an effort to connect Bell Labs with the real word challenges faced in the market, this effort unfortunately falls short. 
 - An unbelievable amount of time is spent in presentation and demo preparations, and relative little in solving the problem at hand. The more buzzwords you put on your presentations, the better. Often the presentations are misleading, because they make claims that don't hold, or omit to mention important limitations.
 - There is a large amount of duplication of work across teams, due to lack of communication, or simply because different managers want a piece of the pie of the next Big Thing (e.g. analytics, ML, Cloud)
 - Compensation is average, and it increases in-pace (that is slowly) with the industry average. In other words, if you are a smart engineer/researcher, you are better off in another company.

review_title: Great Opportunity to Contribute -- Bad Big Picture Leadership
job_title: Head of Services and Support in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: For self-starters, this is a place where you can wear lots of hats, contribute in a collaborative environment, share and interact with global teams, and be innovative.  Working for a brand with world-class recognition is a source of pride and opens lots of doors to partners and potential clients.
cons: This company is slow to move and resists fast innovation and execution.  They have really creative and smart people, but they can't get the job done fast enough or with the quality and innovation necessary to compete in the smartphone marketplace.  Their new leadership, blended with the old leadership, is disconnected with the consumer -- especially in the U.S.  Would have been a better move to develop on the Android platform than MS's.  They do not take advantage in a productive way of the immense talent they have in their global teams and have released many thousands who knew how to execute.  Too bad, because the Nokia brand (especially in Europe) is still strong and people want the company to succeed.  Nokia is no longer a great place to work, sadly.

pros:
Great benefits, great work culture and pretty decent pay. Pay varies more with business lines and relations with managers than performance though sustained performance never goes unrewarded.

Nature of work can be routine or exciting depending on business line and role. Very structured and planned work for most of the business lines except the new 5G portfolio.

Have almost limitless access to decades of expertise and various experiences from around the world using internal yammer communities. Lots of exciting training material and open culture that promotes innovative collaboration.
cons:
Not the best paying company, and neither the provider of ground breaking innovative technologies. 

Due to large corporate structure, some out of the way decisions are pretty slow and need lots of bureaucratic steps or political connections. Its good that regular work is completely transparent to these bureaucracy, but innovation and risk taking is limited.

pros:
- the overall atmosphere is really friendly. It's not the company where you go in with stomach cramps every day, or work orvertime for long period of times.
- there are some pretty smart folks around, and they are very helpful
- the office looks nice, and functions well, office gym is a big plus
- managament is fairly flexible in terms of working hours
-  in certain projects you can learn a lot, and improve with your carear
Overall I think it's a really good place to work, if there is more to your life than your job.
cons:
- lots of old technologies, and lack of real innovation, but right now there is some slight change
- slow decision making in management, afraid of responsibilities
- some project can use really outdated technologies, but to a certain point, it's understandable, it's telecom. /* better safe than sorry */

review_title: Very low basic and bonus compared to competitors
job_title: Sales Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Training and Development opportunities only
cons: Very low basic and bonus compared to competitors

review_title: Virtual work environment which has its pros and cons. A very globalised MNC company as there is diversity.
pros: Work time flexibility, some managers encourages work life balance and some parties events for staff.
cons:
1) Obstacle in career development ie transfer to other job roles in other countries. This subject to your line manager's own manager to decide and approve on mobility. Personal career development plan is just theory but not in practice. 

2) Work load add ons as headcount backfill process takes time or rejected due to hiring freeze back since US finance crisis from year 2009. Most employees handle dual/triple roles with beyond job scope. Also, the year 2011 announced worldwide headcount restructuring plans demoralised each employees years of hardwork.

pros: In Nokia, you can enjoy work life balance. Managers are decent. You will not see any bureaucracy at least in Nokia Bangalore. Also if you are good technically, you will be respected and valued very well. Also Nokia follows "very human" as one of its key values and that is visible even when the company is facing fierce competition and it had to cut down head count. The Nokia gave very good support to all the affected employees. Also the company is transparent in all the communications to employees.
cons: Salary is ok but not very good. Nokia is not paymaster. Lots of processes and management overhead because of the big size of Nokia.

review_title: Great company to make a career
job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros:
- Work-life balance and flexibility
- Company culture
- Career possibilities

It's a huge and good company, with lots of opportunities but don't expect to be carried in you manager arms. If you want something, you need to make it happen.
Career and personal development processes are well defined and there are plenty of official tools to manage those process. Again, don't expect your manager to prepare everything to you.

People are kind and helpful, managers are normally supportive and willing to help, but usually are overbooked and have no time to be pro-active.

All in all, it's a good place to work for both people who like a more laid back environment, 9-to-5 job with no much stress (and still feel part of a great thing) and for people who have more ambition and want to climb.
cons:
- Real estate conditions:
  - Amadora office was refurbished, but it's quite crowded
  - cafeteria and vending machine was placed in spaces with no windows, low ceiling, bad access and insufficient space. Sometimes, a simple morning coffee feels like a mosh pit.
- Country policies for travels and expenses are much more strict  and complex than other countries

review_title: Great place to work but only at the beginning of the career
pros:
Great atmosphere

There is a lot to be learnt for people with no experience / interns

Benefits

Tax break (the right to use author way of tax reporting)
cons:
Salaries are lower than offered by other companies in Kraków 

Limited possibilities of competency development, no approvals for attending technical conferences 

There is no new things to learn except company specific stuff after  working 2/3 years in projects 

Very poor work culture - the most important for management is to keep project deadlines which are set unrealistically  (overtime / weekend work is present in almost every project, from time to time it's even obligatory), almost all projects are delayed and exit criteria are descoped to meet project KPIs / milestones 

Huge attrition of experienced engineers which are being replaced by working students. Low number of engineers with > 5 years of experience 

Complicated organizational structure (line managers, project managers, product managers,  program owner managers, product owners etc)

Severe structural changes ( should be called as revolutions) performed 2/3 times in a year

pros:
1. Flexible work timings.
2. If you get a good manager, life as a woman employee will be wonderful. Everything depends on manager irrespective of what is written in the policy.
3.
cons:
1. Compensation is very less compared to market standards. There is a lot of difference in salary of men and women employees of the same experience. As a lady you will have a lot of disadvantage in terms of getting hikes in the team if most of the team members are males and if they work till late. They will be preferred for hikes.
2. If you stay in the company for long, you tend to lag very behind in terms of the opportunities and salary.
3. Company is not employee family friendly. You cannot take your family members up to your seat except for family connect events. Even for a small infant they will ask for temporary badge.
4. Cafeteria is too small and congested.
5. Space has become too cramped. 6 people are sitting in place of 3 people.

review_title: Decent for a living, but dull, and at times frustrating
pros: The company offers alright starting compensation and decent benefits. It fosters a respectful, down-to-earth culture among engineers, and sets more or less reasonable expectations for them. Work is usually paced well, and there is rarely an expectation to do overtime and such. If you're happy with doing things quickly and getting tickets out the window, you'll be just fine here.
cons: You have to be happy with doing things quickly, getting tickets out the window and forgetting about them, because there are pretty much no opportunities for personal development and growth. You're expected to do 'the job', not 'a better job each day', because the former earns the company money more immediately. I mean, it's a megacorp, and it shows. Working here, you're stuck with a bunch of inefficient tools and slow processes. Decision making is a mix of top-down and "I'll talk to that other team about it". You'll see either an allergic reaction or a laugh from your colleagues any time you mention 'documentation'. True to the meme, you'll spend a bunch of time in useless meetings that could've been an email or simply take too long. And good luck and godspeed if you want to improve your everyday working environment.

review_title: An incredible place to work though in the middle of an adaptation process
pros: It is a great working environment, they really care about employees, there are a lot of benefits even for interns. It is a really friendly and open environment. People are helpful and friendly, the place is nice and clean, we got everything we needed to perform our job, working hours were very flexible yet still people managed to be efficient. It is easy to perform independent research as well as to work with the groups.
cons: The research division at least in Palo Alto is still young, there are not enough people with an adequate level of expertise in key fields for the technological areas they are trying to tackle now. This is probably natural and will be solved as time goes by. As a direct effect, most senior members used to work in different areas don't have clear ideas on what direction to take sometimes.

review_title: It is the Finnish way or no way.
job_title: Product Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Working globally.  Learning new cultures.  The people that work at Nokia are amazing people.  Friendly, and many have experience that can help a person grow and expand their knowledge in the telecommunications industry.
cons: Constant downsizing and restructuring of organizations.  Too many layoffs, creating over-worked employees.  Nokia is slow to market with their products.  They wait for the competition to launch a product, then copy that technology.  Nokia is focused on the Finnish way of doing business.  They seem uninterested in North America and the US based customers.  They are more focused on European, Latin America and India.  Where they make the most money on cheap phones.

review_title: Not good to start one's career-Nokia Bangalore Vrindavan Tech Village.Please dont join
pros:
Vast number of leaves.
Work life balance is a matter of choice.Those who are not interested in doing anything can involve themselves in office politics and survive.
Cab facility which is pretty decent.
Free mobile and bills
cons:
Salary below market standards.
Company is in huge loss ,hence impacting the huge bonus component they project.
Very poor compensation to freshers from all colleges except IITs.
Bad projects which is like every1 does the same work which is testing across all teams.
Inexperienced Managers who are not capable of doing anything except to shout at employees
Micromanagement after a new Director took over,includes dirty politics.
Very bad hikes.
Certain team try to save their asses off even though there is no future in Nokia.
Windows phones is a good thing to come in future but not in the near future which is a disadvantage for ppl looking for long term career plan.
90 % of the crowd are incompetent people.So if u are from a top college as a fresher or from a good company with a decent technical background then frustration is sure to creep in.
Worst work space.All are interested in looking into what others do in office rather than minding their own business.
Dont expect team lunch,team outings.
With the present company situtation it is more likely that the cab facility and unlimited mobile bills likely to get axed.

pros:
The reason why I wake up every morning and come to work at Nokia is because I feel that I am empowered.

I feel empowered by the Nokia values, which are very aligned with my personal values and guide me in my decision making every day. There is no micromanagement needed because the commonly shared values pave my way.

I feel empowered because I can share even the craziest ideas without shame or fear to be laughed at. And the ideas get a new, even greater spin when shared with my very creative and international colleagues. I see many of my ideas getting real.

I feel empowered by my manager who trusts me, who discusses with me, listens to me and is interested in my opinion. I feel I can make a true difference.

I feel empowered because I can be myself.
cons:
Nokia has gone through a tough turnaround, which has made the people very careful. 
Careful about what they share and with whom they share it with. This makes people to hide behind processes and official procedures. There is still some way to go before this company is internally fully open & transparent.

review_title: Good at first, but not a good place to stay long term.
pros: When I first joined Nokia, I found that it was a nice place to work, and there was lots of interesting technology around. The other engineers around me where friendly, and there was a nice collegiate atmosphere. The non cash benefits are good.
cons:
The internal system of salary reviews and appraisals makes it very hard to get a promotion or meaningful pay rise without switching jobs internally, so if you the type of person who likes to stick with the same job year in year out then your starting pay grade will be the same for years.

There appear to be a lot of waste of space middle managers, who manage by spreadsheet and are incapable of decision making. (Friends in other departments have told me the same). If you get one of them as your immediate line manager then your job will be much harder than it needs to be.

review_title: Excellent place to work but poor strategic decision making by senior management
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work environment with very bright and talented colleagues. Exciting industry making tangible products that you can later see advertised on TV and in the hands of consumers.
cons: Senior management made a series of poor strategic decisions like adopting touch screen Smartphones too late, launching a true Smartphone OS years after competitors, and then betting exclusively on Windows Phone instead of implementing a more risk diverse approach like Samsung and others by supporting Android and WP concurrently. The result is known and after Microsoft bought what remained of the device units of Nokia, they decided to lay off 18k employees and dismantle what once was a thriving Finish cell phone maker.

review_title: Be less vertical, and more agile and innovative.
pros:
Very good work life balance. 

Some smart and pleasant people around. A respected company to have on your CV.
cons:
No matter how skilled or talented you are, you're likely going to find limitations in progressing your career or really being listened too, unless you move to Finland or Munich. 

Very vertical organization, means line managers do their most to keep resources in their team,  even when that resource would be more useful to the company elsewhere (and the employee has made a good case to show this). This often means your career can often take second place, to your line managers aspirations and plans. Line managers are mostly folk who have stuck around from when they joined Nokia or Siemens 15 years back. 

Product management, is very old style. Far too many people involved too early, creating a waterfall model (even though they think it's agile). Its very much still stuck in the hardware product management approach, which is not the approach to take to the software world. The result of this, is you see thousands of Euro's poured into products, which have very little market feedback at all.

review_title: Good at the beginning, but needs some changes done to keep more experienced developers happy.
pros:
Good to get first experience. It's easy to get in with a relatively good salary (for a beginner).

Some projects can be quite challenging and fun.

Everyone is welcome to present their own ideas.

Lots of really nice people.

IF you get to be a part of a good team, you'll learn a lot...
cons:
...but some teams consist of people who don't know what they're doing and the management doesn't seem to care enough to do something about this. More experienced employees leave, because of low salaries, work-life balance issues.

Chaos. Sometimes you have to really fight to get all the information you need if you don't know the people who have it.

It's possible to get a good salary when you start, but nearly impossible to get a good raise unless you decide to leave.

The management at times doesn't understand that 9 women can't give birth to a baby in a month.

Work-life balance and job quality will highly depend on the division you'll get into.

It can get quite toxic in some circles and the management doesn't always care.

review_title: Not a suitable place for millenials or people in their 20s or 30s
job_title: Manager, Financial Planning & Analysis in Munich, Bavaria
pros:
- very strong cost discipline allows the company to stay profitable at an operating level
- In general, people have a lot of respect for each other, complete antithesis of a cut-throat culture
- Language of company is English, whichever office you work in
- Great work life balance
cons:
- Company is hesitant in taking bold bets in a fast changing technology world
- Too much reliance on CSPs as customers who themselves are struggling to increase their revenues
- Designations are completely out of tune with what is happening in the outside world
- Restructuring every 2 years means you are going to be shunted around in different teams . You are likely to get the message, "be happy to keep your job, forget about career progression"
-

pros: Flexible, Less pressure, Offices at both Noida and Gurgaon
cons: Bad Ambience, Complex Hierarchy, Bad Management

review_title: A once great company brought low by weak management
pros: Nokia was the best company I worked for - in terms of its excellent people, open and collaborative culture, relative absence of corporate politics and, in its day, opportunities for growth and personal development.
cons: Sadly, that is now largely history.  It all started to end around 2010 and since then it has been a sad downwards roller-coaster ride. Management were far too late to recognise the threat from iOS and Android and did not invest enough on alternatives to Symbian.  Then Elop came along and delivered his Burning Platform speech.  The rest is by now an MBA case study in how not to combine the Osborne effect with the Ratner effect.  There have been 3 or 4 major down sizings in as many years and very many good people have now left.  Morale has been deteriorated with each restructure and few - even amongst senior management - still believe that there is light at the end of the tunnel.  And the culture - once Nokia's great strength - is becoming ever more American, ever more political.

job_title: Learning Solutions Consultant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The opportunity to work for a global company and in particular as a former Nokia employee, an opportunity to be part of start up with 60,000 employees from day one.
cons: Post jv, restructure and extreme competition placed management in a tough position where they had to reduce operating costs drastically to compete.  This movement and lack of real comunication of company vision affected team performance and overall moral.  At this point the biggest issue is lack of trust between employees and management.

pros: Very nice work&life balance, good newcomer salary, multicultural environment, home office possibility, plenty open positions
cons:
Annual salary increase is kinda pathetic, even if you are a good employee with many plus activities/roles over your main job. I really don't understand why is it worth for the company to educate good employees and not paying them accordingly, so after 3-4 years they all go to competitors - or at least those who want to proceed with their carriers or earn decent salary for their work. Unfortunately this behavior is visible on the SW quality and milestones also which got noticed by the customers and causes many dissatisfaction. 
I really hope upper management will make the necessary steps and start to pay the good employees, otherwise it'll be really bad in the next years.

review_title: How it feels to work for Nokia
pros:
Excellent support and open access to all local and global documentation, other project experiences, technical details, etc.
Flexibility to work remote,
Easy work environment.
cons: Average salary with relatively low year to year raises. Some extremely high number of working hours (not always, but when needed it's brutal!). Like any other big company, there are some bureaucracy, high competition for high positions. Less and less attention on line management aspects, very little investment on individuals and very little attention on people's needs, conditions and motivations.

review_title: A company pursuing changes for success
pros: Salary is good and stable. Company culture is easy and no challenge. Problems are identified quickly by Senior leadership team and changes are initiated quickly.
cons: Senior leadership team are aware of Nokia's tough situation in current market share, product is not the best, on time delivery was not committed due many bad decisions (incomplete achitecture design, frequent merges and transfers) and bad feature planning. But Senior leadership team have a vision that the company need to adapt to up-to-date process  - DevOps - SAFe in order to change team's WoW to a healthy way so that previous mistakes won't happen again. But the cost is really big and adaptation takes time. It's like making a bet. if you don't change, you will died. so better to change. but if too much time spent for the change and still do not get there, then will still die.

review_title: Used to be great, but with frequent reorgs, less qualified people get best roles based on who you know, not what you do.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: There still are some great people and managers there, but depends on which group your in. Vacation time is the only thing that still is great, if only you weren't too busy to actually use it!
cons: Too frequent reorganizations, too late in critical decisions, too far behind competition, inability to trust global leaders. Expect more downsizing so the old Nokia beast can be more quick to respond, as the giant takes forever to learn from past mistakes. Don't know how Nokia will continue to attrack new talent, there is a significant amount of risk. There are lots of dissatisfied employees based on "nomination" process over the more traditional qualification review to place people in new roles after each reorganization, so it really is important who you know. If you are Finnish or have worked in headquarters, you already are ahead of the rest no matter how qualified you are.

review_title: Stagnant Growth, Flexible Hours for R&D
job_title: R&D Engineer in Arlington Heights, IL
pros:
Very flexible work environment.  Everyone gets a laptop can mobile phone and can generally work from anywhere, any time.  Since Nokia R&D groups are spread across world, work is going on 24 hrs a day and staff can shift hours to best fit with personal life and current work assignments.  Although it can lead to working 24/7 if one's not careful!

Even with the constant heavy workloads, most engineering staff are friendly and willing to help one another.
cons:
No career advancement opportunities since Nokia is stuck in cost cutting mode for some time.  Offices provide very limited amenities -- no gym, cafeteria, public transit, etc.  No company paid celebration activities, although staff and local management kick in some $$ occasionally for picnic or potluck.

Senior management tends to sign up to more work than staff can handle, leading to long hours and constant schedule slips.  Certainly not an issue unique to Nokia though.

review_title: Disappionting... But Happy to had a job and the opportunity !
job_title: IT Specialist in Arlington Heights, IL
pros:
6% company match for 401k, Bonuses
Co-Workers are Great !!! Local managers really do care about you and try to help. 
Nice Vacation / Holiday time if you get to take it.
cons: They talk work life but I had always worked 70 hour weeks and always lost vacation time. Seem to care more about the workers in Finland who can take a month off with no problem and only work 9 to 5. All the good perks in the Arlington Heights office have gone away and the campus is starting to become run down. Poor communication. Most of HR is useless. Project dates seem to be pulled out of the sky with no real thinking of what really needs to be done and correct timelines. Need to use IT project managers in the US from the old Motorola more for the Global projects.

review_title: Be cautious when considering Nokia Technologies (division of Nokia Corp)
pros:
This review is specifically for Nokia Technologies, headquartered in Sunnyvale, CA USA and a part of Nokia Corporation.  

The company enjoys many of the perks common to Silicon Valley, with decent pay and good benefits.  The work life balance is reasonable.   There are some very interesting technology projects under development and the company has hired some very talented people who are nice to work with.
cons: The company has brought in new executives who have little experience running a products business, so there is a heavy reliance on consultants to get anything done in this space.   The company culture is also quite different than "old" Nokia, so be prepared for that- there is a remarkable lack of trust and transparency for such a small company.   The focus seems to be on style over substance, and doing things instead of doing things right.   Fact based, disciplined decision making is not really emphasized.

pros:
Training. 
Company was properly managed in the 95-2005 period by a respectable banker.
Famous Nokia values.
Great matrix management.
cons:
Since 2005: 
Chaotic redundancy programme that shed great people every year.
Challenged managers focused on saving their jobs and many other things.
Challenging people: Lacking transparency.
Challenging salaries - approx 40% below industry norm for my role. Fact.
New starters are attracted by initially good salaries which don't keep up with times.
The longer you work there, the more you miss a proper job,
New company still run by same non-banker CEO. 
He has been there more than 7 years. You read the reports and form your own conclusions.
Final salary pension scheme was scrapped. This killed the souls of great Nokians.
Canteen closed, all vending machines became chargeable, fuel cards stopped to new employees.

review_title: Manila TC: People Focus? Pay based on performance? --- is a joke
pros:
Growth opportunities.
Work location and accessibility.
Work schedule flexibility.
No strict dress code.
cons:
Highly political work environment.
Some first line managers are blind, and have low performance expectations. Some don't have a good idea of what good work ethics is.
First line managers spoil and even defend employees who are exhibiting bad attitude and behaviors.
Some people who are really delivering results and contributing to move the company forward are not appreciated and rewarded well.

review_title: Very unstable company that does not care about its employees
pros: None - Almost every employee think in leave the company. For many years there have been pros that could be listed here, but since 2007, when Nokia decided to join Siemens and then buy Alcatel Lucent, we live almost daily with the shadow of job cuts and cost savings
cons: Management does not care about its employees. This system has spread for so long that the company has become a very bad place to work, where you do not know if today is the day of your resignation. Now Nokia appears with one of the leaders in 5G, but to this end, its employees are suffering great stress with cuts and the loss of quality of services, with the transfer of activities to India and Portugal, where wages are incredibly lower .

review_title: Lots of opportunity to go above and beyond - but is it necessary?
job_title: Care Program Manager in Redmond, WA
pros:
- Good salary and benefits
- Highly technical work
- Limited constraints on getting work done - ability to do what's right and needed
- Work / life balance affected by customer issues (cyclical), not bad management - no complaints
- Very diverse group - in most meetings no one person is from the same country
cons:
- "yes men". We give our customers everything they ask for, then wonder why the bottom line is in the red. 
- Similar to above, we probably provide the most hand-holding support to a customer of any vendor. This is a cause of high employee stress.
- Many internal groups simply ignore work, even their own. If you own the response/solution, it's up to you to find another avenue to get it. No accountability for people or entire teams not pulling their weight.
- ATT buyout of TMO US, rumors of Nokia and Siemens ending their partnerhsip, and upper management departures are causing concerns about the future.

pros:
•	Openness to cutting-edge technology contributes significantly to Nokia’s renewal, already well underway
•	Proximity of Nozay campus to Saclay fosters a dynamic start-up company style
•	Innovative environment and progressive attitude of many of the managers allow a good level of autonomy for professional exploration and development.
•	Strong efforts by corporate management to encourage innovation, modernize internal corporate culture, and open up siloed organizations.
•	Numerous venues and forums on-site to promote new and alternative work methods help Nokia stay on top of the latest workplace trends: Garage maker space; Coffee and Connect / Café-débat employee conference series, Colibri grassroots group …
•	Beautiful landscaped campus;  comfortable, modern buildings and offices create a pleasant work environment.
•	Numerous amenities – excellent quality cafeteria, on-site gym, full service concièrgerie (dry cleaners, shoe repair, beauty salon, optometrist, etc etc) , Colombus Café gourmet coffee shop, Auchan Drive grocery pick-up station – all fabulous time-savers making it a practical place to work.
•	Telecommuting 2x/wk favors work-life balance
cons: •	Persistent financial difficulties hamper salary evolution. The only way to get a raise… is to change jobs: Doesn’t encourage continued excellence in a given position.

review_title: Some good, some bad, and a lot of material for Dilbert cartoons!
job_title: Lte Test Engineer in Murray Hill, NJ
pros: Interesting leading-edge work in telecommunications.  For the former Alcatel-Lucent parts of the company, the culture was inclusive, professional, and open.    It took some time for the former Alcatel and former Lucent groups to come together but in the end they made good teams.  While working with teams across many times zones was always a challenge, everyone seem to be making a genuine effort to be productive.  If you gain respect from management, you can be given a lot of leeway and trust without much management "help".
cons: Recent take over by Nokia might bring back a silo culture.  Too many management layers. And, for many years there has been too much emphasis on the current financials, with yearly changes in strategic plans.  With so much focus on cash, financials, and the numbers, engineering and development resources are considered assets rather than partners.  Overall, this is not surprising, as that is the "best-in-class" executive style these days.

pros:
+ good for beginners - trainings and so on
+ some focus on quality
+ really cool people
+ probaby better than small companies if you're not a devop type(jack of all trades), yet worse than some other corporations
cons:
- too much politics and pretending, corporate talk
- salary not competitive, sometimes you need to leave company and get back to get a raise or salary similar to less experienced dev, which is simply ridiculous
- lack of expert contractors / technical leaders
- too many scrum zealots, just do what book says and use the tools we gave you
- overtime, some sites are working hard, some not, taking advantage of it

review_title: Above-average benefits and Work/Life balance are the only exceptional things about working for Nokia
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Irving, TX
pros:
Work/Life Balance... you can pretty much name your own hours and people come and go as they please much of the time.

Benefit are good versus the competition, at least they were back when I joined.
cons:
The Irving campus is so far from Finland sometimes it seems we might as well be a 3rd party.
There's very little training made available to employees.
You can never travel anymore, even if it would really help the project.  No one wants to spend the money.
There's pretty much no leadership in Irving... just a bunch of small groups banded together in the same office building.
The working environment is "open"... a bunch of short-walled cubes that makes it easy to sit around and chat, hard to get work done.

pros:
Good for Line Management Function
Good for 9 to 5 job
cons:
- Nepotism - It is in Blood of Nokia
- Politics - Very evident
- The So called Gods (Line Managers) takes full benefit of man power reduction due to restructuring. There is no relationship between your performance and job safety.  If you question your line manager or HR they make sure that you will not be rehired. In there HR database the HR and Line manager put a remark and it will make sure that you will not be rehired.
- The Employe engagement survey is a big eye wash. It is a way to identify the unsatisfied person in group. The manager then try to take such unsatisfied person out by spoiling his rating or making him a part of man power reduction.

job_title: Software Test Engineer in Murray Hill, NJ
pros: Murray Hill is the former base of Alcatel-Lucent, and now base of Nokia since the acquisition on Jan 2016. Here we have Bell Labs and the best telecommunication engineers working around. Either Nokia or Alcatel-Lucent has the tech/engineering in their blood, and the engineers here are nice, not like some software engineers from financial industry, payment industry (where I have been working before). These telecommunication engineers have a bundle of knowledge over this industry.
cons: Because of Huawei's rising, Nokia, Cisco, Ericsson, and previous Alcatel-Lucent are all losing their percentage of this industry. Some departments in Nokia may cutting jobs now, ex the previous wireless department of Alcatel-Lucent might be cut off since the acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent by Nokia

pros: Salary and benefits was typically good, work / life balance was okay.  If Nokia can get back to the point where it was in the early 2000's, it would once again be a great place to work.  Nokia employees felt valued every day!
cons: Changes in Nokia strategy has resulted in many many people losing their jobs, demoralization of those who remain, constantly stressful work environment, and people no longer feel valued as an employee.  Additionally, workspace flexibility has been reduced significantly.

pros: We are doing some exciting things with newer technologies (although there is some support of older).  Good work hours.  The people seem decent.  There's little pressure for a decent developer, but there's opportunity for challenging work.
cons: It's a big corporation with all the nonsense that entails.  Inflexible about hours and work from home (depending on the group).  Some people have been damaged by big corporation management.  I run into a lot of cynicism caused by that.  But everyone who has ever worked a big corporation knows what I'm talking about.

pros: Great manager, most of the team is friendly and fairly new to the company.
cons:
Job was (over)sold as a linux admin job and it's not. Most of the work is application support, creating accounts, standard copypaste scripts. Nothing out of the ordinary. Unlike other sysadmin jobs you don't have to work with lower level parts (eg. server hardware, storage, esxi, vcenter). There's A LOT of KPI's and report to be done and very little technical stuff. If you are coming as an L2/L3 linux admin, this you should ask yourself first if you want to further develop you skills or if you want an easy and cosy job with little career growth oportunities.

Another thing to have in mind is that even if you get hired, that doesn't mean that you have a project to work on. Usually after a project is contracted by the company it can take a few months (even up to one year) until you can actually connect to a server and start working on operations. During this time there's a lot of training. Most of it being useless or very boring.

job_title: Software Test Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: To work for the largest mobile handset manufacturer is a pleasure.  The staff are great and people are motivated to do a good job.  Work environment and facilities are great.  It is very motivating and the staff reflect off of that.  Recognition is greatly looked upon as in certain teams.  Depending on the Manager, your work will be recognized by others quite well and room for growth is possible.
cons: Too much re-organization going on.  Nokia needs to stay competitive especially in the North American Market where they are drastically falling behind in all the latest trends.  We have great products, but they don't come out in time and it always seems that we're the followers instead of the innovators.  Senior mgmt are now encouraging that and restructuring the organization in a way so that we can create products and not platforms.  Hopefully this transition will create just that and get us back on top and become that company we were once before.

review_title: Great company with many great people.
pros: Great people, great culture. Lot's of very smart people that know what's needed to win and generally people are great to work with. There's a high level of information sharing, and people are always willing to help and share. The new CEO is a definite plus and his focus on accountability is much needed - let's see it implemented.
cons: Too many reorganizations too frequently. People never get into their role before they get moved. This also means that your job becomes a networking exercise, and day to day business is becoming more about how to keep your job and get the next one, than actually helping Nokia get stuff done and win. Because of this the good talent is leaving Nokia faster than they can find new, i.e. the people who actually know how to win go elsewhere and become competitors best assets.

review_title: You can grow yet relax at the same time...
pros:
- Culture. Everyone respects each other. 
-  Access to cutting edge technologies and enormous opportunity for any innovations.
- Hard work will be recognized and will reflect on the paycheck.
- Not much politics, if u contribute you grow. Have an idea? You will have avenues to showcase.
- Excellent work life balance. No strict timings.
cons:
- No freebies. Tea coffee tastes like drainage. No free lunch or snacks. No sodexos too. 
- In the name of cost cutting, they cut down everything from beverages to daily allowance if you travel onsite. 
- Although salary packages are decent, there is nothing great to ride home. 
- Lazy and incompetent finance team. They make terrible mistakes even while crediting your salary and u need to keep following up with a hundred emails.
- Infrastructure needs to scale up. It feels like working in some railway station with so many people on the floor. Seating arrangements need drastic improvements along with other office supplies.

review_title: Values maybe no longer practiced: Communicate openly, innovate, focus on the customer, inspire, win together
