pros: It seems that the visitors (working on a 457 or other visa) who took over much of management and the technical/engineering positions have some opportunities at Nokia in Australia and New Zealand.
cons: Today (on completion of their CMO>PMO>FMO) nearly all intellectual property, opportunities for training, technical expertise etc. have moved off-shore to their global services delivery centre GDC (GSD) in India, leaves little locally. Hence, virtually no opportunities in ANZ. NSN, is now known as "Nokia" they say is quickly becoming (little more than)an India software house, internal rumours indicate is about to be acquired.

review_title: Good place to work.come and join
pros:
1.really excellent company value "achievements,challenge,respect,renewal". it is not on words but really operate with this value. here you can get recognition right after you achieve something. you can work closely with your boss as no wall seperate you. when there are some issues with your solution or design or your deliverables, you will be challenged but with respect. and you can always renew yourself from different ways e.g class training,online training,even learning by doing during change or new technolodgy development. and diversity is encouraged in daily work.
2.you can development your carrer path from different way(technical/people management/quality/customer focus), there are lots of open position opportunities for you to apply for when you are ready. before that your line manage will help you to dig out your career path, identify the gap to next step and support you to fix the gap to make your ready. you will be quickly promoted and get more compensation budget if you are equipped with high competence and deliver high performance.
3.innovation are highly promoted to motivate your potential
4.work&life is balanced
cons: salary is not so competitive compared with internet company

pros: By U.S. standards they offer a great vacation package. I believe employees start out with 22 annual vacation days.
cons:
Nokia seems to structure their rewards compensation so that the only way to get a significant raise is to change teams or roles, leaving only inflation based raises for the rest. This leads to constant moving within and in/out of the company making it hard to maintain and garner any kind of product expertise. 

Too many managers, often saying different things, hard to know which one is accurate.

Communication between development sites needs improvement.

Too many emails from the CEO trying to encourage hard work and good performance by guilting you into thinking you owe it to the shareholders to get them high returns.

Too many promises about how they are going to improve things but the proceed to change their minds when it actually comes time to cash the check.

review_title: Now mediocre company that has lost it's way
pros:
Flexible work arrangements.
Yammer provides a good way to keep informed with what is going on in different parts of the company.
cons:
Leadership has no credible vision for the future, there's lots of talk of plans, but the only actions are to dress up numbers for the next quarter, even if it means cuts that directly impact customer deliveries now which impact future sales.
Lots of talk of ethics in dealing with customers and government, but ethics are largely forgotten in internal dealings between different parts of the company.
No career path, no future if you are not in the right business unit in the right geography.
Most former Alcatel-Lucent employees have asked for redundancy and are waiting around hoping to get one. There is no apparent future, and a redundancy payout is the only real hope to get value from employment here.
No accountability. Managers can get upset when deliveries are missed, but there are no actual consequences for mistakes or non performance.

review_title: With holds pay and lies when you separate from the company so they don’t have to pay you.
pros: Nothing. This company y is criminal! BEWARE
cons:
Left me to fend for myself as a new manager. No food, only roast and milk, no product to serve the many textured diets. My new staff where in tears because they had been abandoned for weeks. Corporate promises they would help but they have all kinds of excuses. Finally someone went and bought door with a gift card. It wasn’t enough as grocery stores where out of a lot of items. The guy kept the card and the company y charged me $500 saying I had it. The balance wasn’t even $500 as the corporate guy used it. They gave me a bent door key, which I left on the desk, they refused to pay me saying I didn’t return company property. The worst professional experience I’ve ever had. And now they refuse to pay me for almost two weeks of dealing with the crap. 

Stay away from Lucent Food Service. Horrible horrible company.

review_title: Great technology company but going through changes
pros: If you work in mobile networks then this is the place to be, you will work with some of the best minds in the business. NSN's technology (especially LTE and LTE-Advanced)  is world class and product line staff are very approachable. The online training portal is excellent and if you are a self starter you can learn a lot here.
cons: The company is going through a huge cost saving initiative at present which means that if you have come from a company that offers a lot of perks you will probably be disappointed at NSN. The restructuring process has been going on for almost a year which in my opinion is too long given that existing staff need to know that their jobs are secure,

review_title: Good place for girls and 35+ couples.
job_title: Research and Development Manager in Bangalore
pros:
1. Excellent work culture and working environment.
2. Flexible timings. Work from home options available.
3. Few very good managers who offer maximum support.
4. Most people are talented and good to work with.
5. Much better than service based companies. 
6. Good place to prepare for exams or do business in parallel.
cons:
1. Cheap ways cost cutting.
2. No performance based hike - based only on experience. (At least to my knowledge)
3. Very bad initial training for freshers (Still, few teams have better training).
4. Competence not up to the mark with few seniors. Lack in very basic programming skills. 
5. No IPR related knowledge across people and we are R&D Engineers. Pride !!!
6. Roles are created for people and not people for roles. Too many, Too many managers.
7. Poor employee retention policies.
7. NSN, a good place for people who show-off. (Re-iterating from a colleague - found it to be very matching)

review_title: Top management is not up to the challenge
pros: Opportunities to learn and make an impact on the world. Career rotation. Huge market presence is rewarding because the results of your work are seen all over the world. Good balance between work and leisure. If you want you can work your ass off but it usually won't be rewarded extra.
cons:
Some members of the top management have been in the company too long and/or are just not competent and/or have made far too many mistakes to be credible among employees anymore. 
Claiming employees of being cynical does not help - they must go to restore faith.
Salaries do not usually reflect extra efforts which is not very rewarding.

review_title: Don't work here if you're not Finnish
pros:
Nokia has one of the best commitments to work-life balance I've ever experienced.

The benefits package is at least comparable with the best, and it includes medical insurance.

There are some really good people working here.
cons:
Despite the presence of many good people, there is a lot of dead wood here. I would estimate that about a third of Nokia staff don't really do anything of value. However this is likely to change now that many people are being made redundant.

In relation to those redundancies, it seems quite clear that the ones who are favoured and retain their jobs are the Finns. Since it's Finns who decide, mainly, who gets to keep their job and who doesn't, this looks more than a little bit racist to the non-Finns who work here.

Nokia is now beginning to catch up in smartphones but marketing seems inadequate. We're almost completely off the radar everywhere I look.

review_title: Bad Management, no strategy, no control but  good Salary!!
pros:
Excellent Salary 
Very good package
Nice colleagues
cons:
- There are some people in higher positions earning lots of money and doing anything like Ana Estevez, Bosco Novak and others. Old Seniors  who do not know what they have to do. 
They should fire all them  starting from  Bosco Novak (the worst manager ever) and hire new talents young people. 
-Bad management was the reason for the downfall of NSN.
-Time and money gets wasted using management techniques like the ones offers by leaders of the Global Services.
-Bad control, discipline, no strategyc, no innovation.
-Bad HR Management
-Employees do not have any motivation any more.

pros: can be a way to announce the existence of your business to consumers who are unfamiliar with your products or services. You get to entice potential customers to try your goods. The idea is that they are going to like it so much that they will come back and buy from you again. You must make your promotion grab consumers but at the same time increase your potential conversion rate for repeat customers
cons: Businesses should realize there is such a thing as a "bad" or low margin customer. It's very hard to recoup a low margin sale. It is possible to get a "new" user who found price a barrier to your overall value prop / brand. Now you have to offer a REALLY great experience (good luck if you are struggling with a whole bunch of discount hounds) to get them to come back at full price! And heaven forbid you have folks in your establishment paying full price (which is what you want!!!) while the groupers are feeding. My verdict - stay away...

pros:
Very strong engineers, but too much reliance on parent company Siemens and 3rd parties for resources to perform work.

Very flexible work environment.  Ability to work from home as needed.  An environment of trust.

Compensation is very good.  Benefits are average.

Executive management is committed to change but it may be too late.  Someone may be looking to take the company off of Siemens and Nokia's hands.

Solid business success in North America, but really hurting elsewhere.
cons:
Very weak PMO although changes are being implemented.

Micro-managing by customer account teams.  Account team "Program Managers" are in actuality, project managers that are not part of the PMO.  

Poor software quality has put the company in dire straits.  Cost-cutting has gone to extremes--termination of coffee service, a travel ban except where specially authorized.

pros:
- it seems to be a fresh company, embracing quite fast what is new, especially the virtual communication 
- very good work-life balance, possibility to  work from home
- good benefits
- good communication from top management -> simple employee
- good lessons learned  method - sessions are held on a daily basis
cons:
- due to the current merger with Alcatel, many processes are overlapping, also people are frustrated as a lot of changes are happening for the moment inside the company. 
- training's are held exclusively online
- outsourcing of some functions such as accounting and IT support which  leads to lost time in explanations over the phone or via a ticket, things take long to get solved compared to companies where this departments are inside
- people tend to run from responsibility, they hide behind one mail
- there are a lot of interactions with colleagues from India, you constantly need to adapt the communication to get things done

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Cloud, MN
pros: - Good company to work with telecom mindset.
cons:
- HR process is slow and contract are very general therefore once you get into the company, global company policies highly overwrites the contract annual incentives / realignment every year on the policies.
- reorg is very frequent
- Enterprise mindset given a less preference hence sustainability and growth will be very slow.
- Global leadership roles for expat folks are given with no prior experience on leadership roles.
- leaders are weak to network on social platform

review_title: Confusing directions, too much politics, information hiding
pros:
- Most of the software assets are freely accessible. This is great if you are able to find time and contribute & learn
- Global management is good, has good ideas / intentions
- Great colleagues outside India who know a lot and are willing to share it if you show interest
- Great place for Project managers - not much technical abilities asked for. Only communications and presentation skills needed
cons:
- Complex matrix structure
- No transparency in hikes, bonus payments, promotions
- Managers living in ivory towers, taking all the credits but passing all the blame
- Local managers spent a lot of effort on info hiding! This is contrary to global executives who are very open & humble
- Quality of middle managers in R&D is pathetic. seems like the top bosses deliberately hired people less capable than themselves to secure own jobs.

review_title: I've worked in many companies, this one I call home!
pros: Truly global work culture; active internal job market; professional colleagues/subject matter experts, good benefits like free fitness classes and health services on campus; annual bonus opportunities; fair salary; good ergonomic work environment with reliable IT support, tools; flexible hours/possibility to work remotely when needed; vibrant atmosphere; required learning modules annually;  frequent restructuring can be disruptive but also empowering; decision-making relatively flat; regular reviews with line manager to stay on track with agreed targets and longer-term career development
cons: Open office concept can be very distracting, counterproductive at times; time zone challenges can mean long work days or needed flexibility on part of employees to work outside normal hours; very large organization comes with challenges to avoid silo thinking and acting; many tools/processes to learn - some not very intuitive; fast paced industry also means fast paced work and race to meet deadlines - can be both motivating and draining; can be tough for some to see individual contribution in such a large organization but there tools in place for individual recognition

review_title: Leadership encumbered by some poor leaders, and employees deflated by below market wages. Stay away!!
pros:
Global recognition and brand name
Leader in market 
Lot of opportunities for new challenges
cons:
Lot of dead wood in middle and upper management 
Does not care for employees, CEO keeps harping on driving down cost and does not ask for how well are we compensating compared to industry, at least for our best people we would not want to lose. I doubt they even have a list of people they would want to retain at all costs
Some LT leaders keep a layer of mediocrity below them so they can preserve themselves and they have been there for years! CEO needs to be smart to refresh his leadership team and look past the nice power points being shown by mediocre leaders who their organizations hate like mad but it is confounding how they manage to survive

review_title: Almost 10 years together and still great place to work
pros:
- great place to deal with really challenging projects
- you give a lot but you receive flexibility, ability to manage and implement important changes
- latest Telco Technology is there 
- maybe I was lucky but all the bosses I had gave me huge trust and flexibility
- if you want, you can change your career according to your needs
- atmosphere! 
- a lot of CSR activities around you
- almost 10 years in Nokia Wrocław but every new year gives a real opportunity to meet new people, to start new project, to do and check your skills in real projects
- proper amount of informations 
- great handling during current crisis
cons:
- some decisions should have done earlier (it sounds like a buzz word without the context but it came to my mind)
- when new projects starts even so obvious mistakes are making (in some areas lessons learned process is not in place)

pros: Very virtual work environment, employees can work from home as needed, decent suite of tools available to to support work at home.
cons: Work life balance is defined as working all the time and keeping your family last on your list.  When there are cuts, all sites outside of Finland take deeper cuts than in Finland.  Despite claims by Nokia that there is a secondary world headquarters in the U.S., the power base remains in Finland.

review_title: Good employee when I started, now has become very average.
pros:
- International work culture
- get a chance to work with different sites and people
- Good values and lot of emphasis on everyone to follow those
- Most managers support good/work life balance
cons:
- Different units/organization work in silos and do not cooperate much, Each one is interested in achieving own targets rather than looking at overall or big picture
- Very frequent re-orgs and changes which create confusion in employess mind and affect morale
- Below par pay or huge difference in pay even for employees with similar experience/competence
- many of the policies are just on paper. and depends heavilty on the individual manager. There is no clarity on pay, internal job trasnfers and promotions and those are just situation or luck based and on the manger.

review_title: You'll gain experience along with a great work/life balance work environment.
pros: Nokia is very flexible when it comes to work arrangements. Most of that depends on your direct manager, but at the very least, you'll get to work from home at least one day per week. Others have had the ability to work more from home since their direct line manager is not locally-based. However with this flexibility also comes with traveling to the motherland (Finland). On the bright side, you'll get to earn miles so fast that you don't know what to do with them.
cons: Promotions seem to depend on your direct line manager. While I worked there for over 9 years, I rarely had the chance to move up or extend my experience beyond my responsibilities. Others who joined at the same time have moved on to higher positions with better responsibilities.

job_title: Research and Development Engineer-2 in Bangalore
pros: Nokia Siemens Networks came into existence only few year back earlier it was Com Division of Siemens and Com division of Nokia, I was part of Com Division of Siemens which was Siemens Communication Software it was one of the best places to work in India(although its existence in India was less) approach to work from every individual within the organization was excellent, each individual was ver innovative, after the merger with Nokia many things changed many policies changed, now opportunities have become wide open there are lot of things that might change in future and also management is thinking how best they can improve the organization looking forward how best business can be done, taking lot of innovative steps at management level.
cons: very tough to describe.. there is not much transceperancy.. every individual who is still working in projects that were part of Siemens Communication Software earlier are afraid of their future :(

review_title: The best telecom company in Wroclaw
pros:
If you want and if you are interested enough you can stay in touch with technology that will come to the markets only in the future, which makes this work pretty interesting - you have opportunity to face problems that not many faced before.
Nice office, rather young team, more and more investments in Poland, better and better labs.
Competitive salary, flexible working hours. Job rotation/horizontal transfers possible.
cons:
That's the only telecom company in Wroclaw... so it's not that easy to leave or change...
It's also not that easy to get salary increase, so you better fight for a good salary at the very beginning.
It's pretty difficult to have vertical promotion, so it's also better for you if you are rather into engineering and don't even think about any change to more manager-like position in the future.

pros:
The pros of working in NSN is that it is one of the biggest telecom companies in the world to work for. The name has excellent recognition due to the branding of the previously independant companies, Nokia and Siemens Communications.

The recent Global Financial Crisis has brought spending to a standstill but they had some positive policies in place such as paid instructor-led training every 6 months, broadband allowance and good on-call support rates.

Some of the other benefits include corporate company days where all staff go and spend a night at a resort and have a lot of fun activities.

The company encourages work/life balance.

Casual dress policy.

New Nokia phones every couple of years!

Games rooms - billiards, table soccer, table tennis.

It's hard to generalise about a global company as the experience will differ from country to country and even manager to manager.
cons: It's a new company so its hard to say whether the cons are with the company or with the economy. The cons at the moment are that all spending is strictly monitored.

pros:
* An international Brand to be proud of.
* Work-Life balance is good
* Large UX team
* Leader in Mobile Technology
cons:
* Absolute chaos in internal project management. Too many people/teams doing the same thing
* Services division in Nokia Bangalore functions like a outsourced unit
* Nokia R&D presence in India is more than 3 years old, Yet, Services Bangalore team is still trying to prove themselves to the Nokia big heads in Finland, UK and US
* Absolute disregard to experienced professionals.
* Absolutely no discipline/science in assigning  grades to people
* Too many people spending too much time working on too trivial projects
* Nokia as a brand seems to be too slow in catching up competition.

review_title: Was a great company to work for at the time
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Nokia culture is team work. Everyone works together and information is being shared with different teams.  People move around depending on which project who is working on. The team works in the same area to make communication easier. People are great.
cons:
Nokia has been behind competition for sometime now. Things are not improving as much as we all have hoped for.
Now medical insurance may not be the best.    .                                                                                                 .

review_title: Recommended from perspective of technical growth in telecommunication domain
pros:
Multinational company dealing with whole spectrum of Communication Service Providers allows to work in various technology areas (radio, core networks, systems integration). Roles related to direct customer projects (like in SI) give lot of opportunities of professional growth, when one seeks the responsibility. After some years of work may have a substantial portfolio of projects done for operators in various countries.
On product side - range of innovative products in several Telco domains allow to work with cutting-edge technology.
Direct (local) line management has good attitude to employees' 'daily matters' which supports work/life balance.
Great team spirit on working level where engagement in order to deliver to commitment is clearly visible.
cons:
Becoming bit too unstable - lot of subsequent reorganizations don't give time to 'settle down' after a change. On has to like a hectic environment to enjoy working @NSN.
Good plans for competence development are often killed by cost factors.

review_title: very dissatisfied and just good to start working
job_title: Solutions Manager in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros:
You have access to the technology and top customers; it is a very known company; it is good to start working because you can learn and work in interesting projects and technologies.
There is no much pressure and you can balance between the work and family.
cons:
The management doesn't care about the career evolution and are only concerned about the cost reduction. They are more focus on  moving the product's development and sub-contract resources in low cost locations such India.
If you are a good technician, you don't have any possibility to access higher positions, unless you become a manager. Majority of the management islocated in Finland, Germany and UK. If you are located in other locations, you have less changes to evolve.

review_title: Great company, shocked by the lack of drive and weak management in Symbian
pros:
Good work-life balance
Competitive compensation
Generally a good place to work and I would work for them again.
cons: Management was poor and weak within Symbian Unit. The Symbian Unit lacked drive to improve and would actively work against change. Many people believed Nokia owed them a living until retirement even if they had 30 more years before retirement. Very political  and people were very protective of their jobs and did not want to change things for the better. People were very arrogant and thought they would always be the leader in mobile phones and just thought IOS and Android never impact them

review_title: Once a great nordic success story now an Asian IT service company
pros:
Good benefits
Healthy work life balance
Ability to coast along doing nothing
cons:
This was once a great innovative Finnish company. After 10yrs with Rajeev Suri at the helm it has become an Indo-Finnish service corporation too big to change and innovate, instead it focuses all its energy on cutting costs and outsourcing work to India. 
Nokia was quite a diverse company but now all management positions are occupied by Indians,  When I left I was the only non-Indian on my team.
Despite many the many cost cutting layoffs, Nokia never dismisses any senior managers, directors or vice presidents. These well paid do-nothing oligarchs simply rotate job roles every 6months to a year.
Also, despite the NAM region being their biggest and most profitable region, all decisions are made by Global, probably at the spa of Karaportii

review_title: Nokia treats its employees very well.  There is a lot of freedom but not much accountability.
pros: Nokia is a very collaborative, democratic organization.  Everyone is free to speak their mind.  Software teams generally choose their own technologies and tools.  The organization has gone agile to some degree.  Employees are treated with a great deal of respect and are well compensated.  Nokia has very progressive environmental policies (e.g. no paper cups; ceramic cups are provided for every employee to use).
cons: The decision-making process is very slow at Nokia.  There is a tendency to "reinvent the wheel" instead of re-using code.  Many Nokians favor open-source solutions rather than Microsoft ones for politicial reasons.  There is very little accountability at the senior management, product owner, and team level.  Finns and Europeans generally receive greater respect.  The North American mobile market is consistently ignored or is not treated as a serious market.

review_title: There are some good technical people, but poor management and hiring strategies
pros:
Relaxed environment.
If you get the right tech lead/guide/architect, one can learn a lot.
Developers who just get smart solutions for problems are recognized at the last, while the guys with bragging rights get it first. (At least doers get it some day)
cons:
Even if you don't work they sometimes don't care.
Immature Management skills.
Poor people management capabilities
The top management want to change the company way of working and bring it back to stability, but they are facing resentment and politics from middle management, so the right message doesn't get passed through, in the org hierarchy sometimes...For example top management wants people to work hard and bring the org back to profit making...This message has been never permeated to the teams my their product management/people managers

review_title: Very hard to progress for technical minded people. Good place to progress for management type people.
pros: Good work life balance, nice canteen.
cons:
Impossible to progress for technical people. Maybe in old days it was possible, but now its impossible. Nokia looks after management types but not the technical minded types. 
Lots of hangers on at nokia. People who been there long time on good salary, but hardly do anything useful.

review_title: Not the best place to be an engineer.
pros:
* Lovely colleagues.
* A great sense of community.
* Some green credentials.
* Honesty in its dealings with other companies.
* Genuinely good engineering in its products.

You were never alone with a challenge: there was always someone that could be asked for an opinion and people would nearly always make the time to help.  Probably the second-best thing I'm taking away from my time there it's that willingness to help and be helped; "The Nokia Way".
cons:
Almost zero opportunity for mobility within the organisation or to renew skills.
Little/no training available - certainly nothing beyond Nokia-specific techniques and tools.
Regular requests to work extra/unsocial hours for no remuneration.
A culture of requiring high achievers to fight hard for recognition.

Some of these are due to the very tight budgets of the last 7 years and, as such, are quite understandable but there comes a point when giving your best in the hope of "jam tomorrow" becomes stale.

review_title: A future facing, fast evolving technology company
pros:
- Lots of flexible benefits such as working from home full time since Nokia understands the trend for flexible and virtual working is only going to increase. It is a modern company which embraces the future and does not look back. It believes in the 'careers without borders' principle. 
- It's a fair and decent place to work which - I rarely meet an unpleasant person in the company -people are nice and friendly and hard working
- The continuous change is exciting and there are lots of opportunities for the company in future
cons:
Although the change can be exciting it can also be unsettling since people are moving and transferring or groups and teams change. The integration with Alcatel Lucent means there is currently a continuous state of flux. This will inevitably subside as the 2 companies have time to integrate. 
- I would like the company to focus more on base pay rather than fringe benefits

pros:
The company is providing WFH facility.
Cab facility is also provided if one gets late while working at night after nine pm.
cons:
1)Work life balance next to zero
2)During increment period some silly reasons will be sited to justify zero percentage increment
3) Regarding exist process:
   a)There is no resignation tool so you will have to send resignation through email.
b)The HR & line manager due to internal  understanding ,will hide all exit related information (e.g. last working day, all clearance)
c)You will have to run from PILLAR TO POST(Manager to HR & HR to Manager)
 but you will not get any information
d)On your last day ,you will be on your knees with tears in your eyes & at the mercy of their will.

I think it will be the worst kind of mental & emotional torture that you will have to experience.

Note : It's not only my personal experience but many of my colleagues have sufferd the same thing

job_title: Business Development Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Nokia is all about mobility - to me it translates to life balance, using mobile communication to improve our communications and ability to connect in our professional lives as well as with our loved ones. Nokia's roots come from Finland and touch nature and environmental values and there is a genuine feeling inside the company to give (to the consumers and society). It is one unique workplace to be at.
cons: Nokia is a very large public company with 100k plus employees with all the processes and rules and bureaucracy you dont have in a small company, also networking with the Finnish people requires understanding of the European/Scandinavian culture and it's goods and bads

review_title: No career growth unless you have a finnish last name!
pros:
Industry leader, Looks good on resume.
Good work life balance. Management allows flexible time and work from home.
Salary and Benefits OK.
cons: Very limited growth opportunities in US. Company mostly takes care of its Finnish employees. They are hand picked for promotion and attractive jobs. Top leaders of the company are almost all finnish. Hard to call it a global company. Most decisions are taken from Finland even for local projects. Nokia still doesn't have a US strategy or US market oriented products and no collaboration with US operators. Career advancement is largely based on how you build relationship with Finnish managers and not based on merit or performance. There are many incompetent managers who somehow hold on to their jobs since company hardly looks at managerial performance.

review_title: Work almost 24/7 and many weekends are gone
pros:
Good salary and package
Good line managers
State of the art facility and tool
Great muti-cultural people and background colleagues
cons:
Not winning enough & important project
Not profitable (Do they know how to run a company to profit or not)
Very dis-organize - Work weekends and nights, work scheduling is  improper
Job future unknown - soldier on
Increment was not given due to fact was ask to give to those more deserve of it  - Those who didn't negotiate well before joining (we have to suffer to for them)
Too many re-organization and policies keep changing (given excuse world is changing, deal with it)
Not enough training given - Force to support and be oncall without proper documents and training.

review_title: Good first job, perspective...not so much
pros:
Good first experience : relaxed work environment, virtually 0 overtime. 
Fair enough benefits, depending on the specific location one is working at.
cons:
As a beginner, right out of school you will most likely be tossed to work on a product that uses out of date techology so embrace the phrase 'for historical reasons..', as a developer this is a major pain in the back.
Gathering competence in the company specific technologies does not help carreer path, unless of course one wants to stay at Nokia for several long years.
Senior dev people are not compensated properly, management does not seem to realize that without seniors, the whole development goes down the tube.

pros:
I love my job. I enjoy what I do and I am good at what  I do.
I have supportive teammates and everyone is really friendly.
cons:
Current Manager wastes too much time on unnecessary meetings, most of which cover topic readily available in emails.
Current Manager puts too much pressure on employees making it hard for us to work on our own pace without disruptions.
Current Manager talks in a way that is discouraging.
Current Manager expects us to work in multiple environments without proper training.  And we are supposed to be effective (Quantity over quality mindset), It would be best if we were to initially master the environment one at a time and by choice.

review_title: •	4+ Years of experience in SharePoint Environment. •	Good experience in SharePoint Administration and Troubleshooting.
pros: If you have two applicants and everything else is the same but one is coming from Apple and the other is coming from a no-name tech company, nine out of ten times the Apple person is going to get hired,” says Jennifer K. Hill, president of J Hill Staffing. “Your employability is equal to your education times the company you work at times the skills you have.
cons:
You keep two valued employees who might otherwise quit to pursue work-family balance issues.

You gain two brains, two sets of enthusiasm and creativity, and two employees committed to your success.

review_title: Dropping market share and demotivated employees
pros: Good work environment, scandinavian corporate culture, strict cost control, home-office and remote work available
cons: Constantly demotivated employees due to permanent cost cutting and lay-offs, the company fails to develop new products, lives out of new releases of mobile network. A carrier is still possible but you need some luck. Thousands of incompetent not value adding middle level managers. The corporate culture is changing for worse since there are fewer and fewer Finnish managers in the corporation. People spend hours in generating reports that nobody reads. Managers spend 50%+ of their time in meetings that bring no value.

review_title: Generally a good place to work -  a big family
pros:
- Flexibility in working hours & possibility to work remotely if needed
- Some benefits in place (ticket restaurant, private health insurance)
- Respect from upper management & withing teams (some exceptions in place)
- Many social activities in place where you can participate, Some employees are actually motivated to give actual effort in such initiatives (this is something that you definitely don't see in other companies)
- Freedom of speech
- Carrier opportunities came up during the site rump up in the last years
cons:
- Salaries are in a quite low level. if you decide to continue in our company here in Athens you need to be ok with low or zero financial growth
- Freedom of speech is being stepped on. Employees quite often have to tolerate with "political attacks" withing the company. Nothing is done there to deal with this situation.

job_title: R&D Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: No dress code, Flexi time, A lot of career opportunities, Office premises are nice. You can watch youtube and use facebook (though I'm not sure anymore how long it will last)
cons: People are not well compensated. Toxic environment, their so called work-life balance is not true, you are almost always required to render overtime. There's a high tendency to get overworked as some teams are undermanned but there are no new hires. Management don't stick to their word, They will promise a fun place to work but in reality, all of these were applicable only 3 years ago. There's no "work and play" environment anymore as they advertise. And despite having having a lot of possible work opportunities, career growth is slow.  Things are also going downhill, there's a lot of changes which doesn't please employees.

pros:
Employees are encouraged to continuosly look for ways to further develop themselves in order to stay at the forefront of technology and build their competencies. And as a Nokia employee, you will find opportunities to live out and enjoy Nokia technology on a daily basis.

Nokia’s reward package includes competitive base pay and excellent opportunities for variable pay. Employees also receive benefits such as medical, dental and paid time off. Nokia offers an industry-leading 401k plan, an employer stock purchase plan and many other programs and perks.

Nokia understands the importance of juggling professional and personal interests, and offers support for meaningful achievement in work, family, friends and self.
cons: Too frequent changes most of which are confusing and unnecessary. Dead wood at management. Many departments function as silos. Everyone wants to protect their back during changes by politics. Very bad at integrating acquisitions.

review_title: A 150 year company in constant renewal
pros:
- Nokia has a long history of transforming itself, moving from one industry to another and create new success. It opens up new opportunity to do different and sometimes pioneering things.
- Good company culture, mostly originated from Finnish/Nordic/Scandinavian culture. Respect for individual, good balance of work and life, less hierarchy, fairly open communication.
- Big enough company to move around, try out new roles and new functional departments, move to different countries.
- Benefits in the US is fairly good, even though decline in recent years.
cons:
- The series of mergers and acquisitions created a confusion of culture and trust level.
- There are uncertainty in employment, due to portfolio and functional overlaps from mergers and acquisitions.
- Base salary and bonus in US might not be as competitive as other technology companies.
- Speed of innovation and execution is relatively slow.
- Personal growth might be limited when the company is not growing any more.

job_title: Solutions Specialist in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: "Good Benefits" Benefits have been decreasing since two years ago but still better than other companies,  Flexible hours and Home Office (it Depends a lot of your manager and workload area).
cons:
It depends a lot of your manager, if your manager is INCOMPETENT,  then you will start feeling  like you were working in Huawei, HR are hiring Managers without Vocation and the required capacity to lead a team, in consequence many people decide to quit Nokia and the teams are full of new joiners and very few experienced resources.  
The salary is too low compared to the complexity and the workload. 
Unless You're Very Lucky and with the help of someone else, dont expect a significant salary increasement  or even a career opportunity path. 
not extra pay for weekend work, or off-business hours work.

review_title: Not a good time to join Nokia
pros:
Great benefits. 
Good work life balance.
Good work atmosphere.
cons:
Lack of a clear sense of direction.
No clear line of responsibility among middle management.
Too many "decision makers" who don't actually make decisions.
Attempting to reinvent the wheel every year making for terrible quality and complete lack of growth as all engineers end up doing is porting from one "next greatest platform" to another. 
Outdated tools - especially for version management, bug management. 
Too many people who have been with Nokia for years and years haven't worked much in other companies and believe they are the best and their way is the only way.
 Also makes for cronysim and people give good reviews to their buddies and newcomers are viewed with suspicion. 
Architect level people simply aren't of the calibre I have seen in previous jobs.

review_title: Experience as Project Manager at Nokia Siemens Networks in Kuwait
pros: flexibility in the work, fair, open and good relationship on the working level and mid management
cons:
Siemens was a great company, Nokia was even greater. after the merger everything went down in high speed. for all my time I spend with NSN there was a 2-Class Employee, 1st class Nokia, Second Class Siemens even all belongs to one company. for the same job and position in the same office some "Ex-Nokia" for 3-4 time the salary as "ex-Siemens" emplyees based on not harmonized benefit plans.
for instance Heath-Recreation Club was paid even 2 years after the merger to them whom received it before (obviously only Nokia), denied to whom which never received it. You should konw that this benfits was crucial in Kuwait because nothing to do otherwise and and the membership cost about 2500 Euro/yer for the familiy.

review_title: Extremely unethical Nokia center to join
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Good for those who are good at politics.
cons: The local management at Fortune Tower Gurgaon is worst what i have seen. Local management pressurize folks to leave if they don't act or work as per their way. They take command of the Fortune tower  as if they own this center and they take all the advantages of the employee policies but don't let rest of the employees take the benefits of the same. Politics is the one thing everyone cares about this center. Management will not communicate with you and doesn't maintain the transparency in the processes. At the time of appraisal, they will just let you know the appraisal and won't discuss anything regarding issues, concern employee is facing and what need to be corrected. Extremely unethical folks are there in the management. Be cautious before joining at this Nokia Center.

job_title: Head of Department in Fleet, England
pros: Was offered the job, pay was negotiable and even included a welcome bonus as they couldn't match what i was asking for. Company has great people with great skills, good collaboration between most forks on an individual basis. Formal communication channels are useless
cons: Company is continuously restructuring/reorganising. Moving people from one department to another with no real strategy or benefit. They no longer invest in the future and have resigned themselves to trying to go head to head with the Chinese on cost and innovation. Not a wise strategy.

job_title: LTE Product Architect in Irving, TX
pros: The lean approach to R&D is somewhat misguided right now (quality issues), however NSN is trying hard to slowly refine it and make it work.  They have made a strong emphasis on Quality, they have narrowed their businesses & portfolio to increase focus on Mobile Broadband Networks products, and they have taken difficult steps with RIFS and streamlining the org.  All steps in the right direction.  I think the company has the right "spirit".  It is still not certain how successful they will be, but their "head" (management strategy) is in the right place in my opinion.  They also encourage lateral moves across functional areas.
cons: Salaries seem low compared to industry.  Not much upward growth opportunity at the moment (understandable due to recent restructuring efforts, hope this gets better soon). Slightly chaotic R&D environment (very lean and scrum team oriented, which is difficult to manage in such a large org).

review_title: Best job I've had so far
job_title: Senior Technical Architect in Manila, Manila
pros:
In random order...
1. Flexible policies
- flexi-time and no time-in/time-out (manage your own time)
- policies are applied in case-to-case basis
2. Premium healthcare
- you can enroll unlimited number of dependents with each having reimbursable medicines/prescription glasses/vitamins on top of outpatient and inpatient coverage
3. Workplace
- laptop with internet and external monitor/s
- continuous improvement driven by employee suggestions
- free coffee /  milo
- monthly Friday night lights (food, drinks, and live band)
- free fruits once a week
- no dress code
- availability of gym
4. Culture
- aggressive in assessing and implementing  changes / improvement proposals from employees
-  very open communication (non-hierarchical)
- minimal experience of managers doing micro-managing (culture actually promotes self-managing teams)
5.  Travel opportunities for development teams
- For Asia - Russia, Japan, China
- For Europe - Finland, Poland, France
- There are also travel opportunities for US
6.  Career Path
- Merit-based not seniority-based
- Lots of options
cons: Hmm I have observed lots of unpaid overtime mostly by their own choice due to maybe pressure to deliver.

review_title: Telecommunication technology  pioneers and one of top employers around the globe,Troubled recent times though
job_title: Senior Solutions Sales Manager in Islamabad, Islamabad
pros:
-Healthy Work Environment
-Strong  and homogeneous organizational culture around the globe.
- Strong technology back bone still leading the innovations and supporting the business in toughest times company has ever seen.
cons:
-Complex internal processes due to too frequent changes in organizational structure.  
- Has lost customer centric approach because of this internal focus.
- High level management has failed to deliver correct leadership to company.

review_title: Good place for managers and pregnant ladies
pros: Good work life balance. Infact more life than work. If you are bit shameless you can work from home most of the time. If you r pregnant you get 9 months paid leave and after that for a year u can work from home. European culture that u can take your time to finish a thing no hurry. Less onsite but if you go u get to stay in the best hotels and enjoy a lot.
cons: Too many managers. They will get external employee from cts or tcs as developer so managers rule here. Every year during hike time top managers will send one depressing mail making u feel forget hike saving ur job will b satisfactory. Top management is clueless as to what is goin on. They will make tail as head as head as tail and expect to show miracle. It doesn't work and they will make as head. I can go on but will stop here.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Can be a nice place to work.   They hire a lot of really bright people.   On par with google in that respect.   The culture of the company is good.   They higher ups try not to screw you at every turn.   Everything seems European.
cons:
Some managers are volatile.   Seem good then they go off on tirade and screw people.   Luckily neither of mine were.

Bonus is supposed to be 15%.   Have not seen anything in the almost 2 years I have been here other than referral fees.  No pay increase either.   Just silence.   
No training.   No opportunity for advancement other than being in a shrinking group and getting ahead via attrition.   (Less people so you can't do as well as your predecessor )

review_title: Good starting carreer before you realise how cheap you are :)
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Warsaw, Masovia
pros:
Good company for starting carrier (first couple of years).
Highly focused on low cost (we are taking off free  coffee becasue we need to save many, few years later - oh, coffee is back, wtf?).
Demanding job with increasing responsibilities not reflected in salary.
cons:
Not best place to work with if you want to work to your fullest potential.
Management decisions focused mainly on lowering cost instead of making emploees feel comfortable and motivated.

review_title: Good position for a fresh grad
pros:
- you're fresh out of college? you'll get in, and it'll be quite good :)
- the team is young, and it's relatively easy to find a clueful person;
- some opportunities to grow *if* you're new to the game

In other words, quite a nice place to gain your experience. Demotivating and annoying in the long run.

review_title: Nokia a great place to work, but not perfect
pros:
-Work/life balance is great
-Lots of great employees (plenty of intelligent people around)
-Company has great market share and innovation potential
cons:
-Stress level is high, likely because the company communication between departments is disorganized and automation is an after thought (or never thought of)
-Overabundance of information in numerous disparate locations.
-Employees rely on technology communication vs face-to-face
-Lots of meetings, many of which are ineffective and inefficient

job_title: Senior Software Design Engineer in Tokyo
pros:
-Relaxed Office Environment
-Needed Trainings are provided
-Work Life Balance
cons:
-Bad Leadership throughout all the way from CEO level.
-People on management level still are not thrive for real change to this ever changing and competitive environment.  Companies always implement changes, but these changes only affect people on the bottom the most.  People on the top are just playing musical chairs, swapping roles.
-Management are rarely responsible for any bad decision they have made.   They stay in their job whereas engineers are blamed by being laid off.
-Bad Salary to start with.  Average yearly pay rise was about 1~3%.  This is pathetic.
-Managers are selfish, only care about their own promotion.

review_title: Times are changing and opportunity in US is limited
pros: The benefits from Nokia are very good compared to most companies. Nokia picks up the majority of the basic costs for healthcare and matches 401k up to 6% total.  Due to distance from Finland, when you start work very early local time, you get flexi-time later in the day to take care of personal business.
cons: Nokia as a whole is contracting back to Finland.  All roles and functions outside of Finland are reduced and even inside Finland there have been reductions.  If the company is not successful with the new Windows Phones in the US Market during 2012, then expect further reductions in 2013.

review_title: Used to be a great company to work for, now some units are still great and some not so much.
job_title: Senior Manager in White Plains, NY
pros: Great benefits, good pay, good opportunities for international assignments, fast paced environment. Mostly small teams and organizations.
cons: No work/life balance, a lot of conference calls that are in the middle of the night. decisions take forever, mgmt not held accountable for their decisions, intense pressure to deliver with very little time and resources. Good ideas can be dismissed if they don't fit current "emergency". Your job security is not based on how good you are but what you happen to be doing or the team you happen to be in. Top performers get laid off regularly, while lower performing people get to keep their jobs just because they were in a "safe" unit. Everybody wants to have a say on everything but no one wants to have the responsibility / accountability for the decisions.

review_title: Outstanding Products - Able to become a great company
pros:
Nokia has the ability to develop great products with a focus on helping people manage and take advantage of daily life. 
Brilliant minds exist within the groups.
Diverse locations offer a global experience to make a difference.
cons:
Bogged down with too deep of a Finnish mindset where flexibility is not the standard. 
Silos of groups, and location policy limiting.  
Listening to the voice of the existing customer base not a strong suit.

review_title: Good place to work but can be better with better management
job_title: Research and Development Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Experienced and technically strong seniors.
Can learn a lot if you will get into good projects.
Rewards are based on your performance.
cons:
Bad management. Project planning are not proper which results in extra work load during release times. Some product managers will try to put unnecessary extra pressure. Sometimes they will call you on weekends even though you don't have work.
War room culture. They will start a war room for each project from the beginning without proper planning. There is no point in that and that never ends well.
Very less hikes.
No extra benefits to employees apart from salary and medical insurance.
HR managers are not reachable at all. They will meet you once in your tenure over there, during your joining.

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Benefits!  

Vacation: A new hire immediately gets a vacation bank of 80 hours Vacation, 40 Hours of Floating and 80 Hours of Family Health (sick, bereavement etc) without needed to accrue. Every year of service gets you more Vacation days. With 5 years I have 200+ hours of vacation. 

401K match:  Nokia matches $for$ upto 8% of total cash compensation. Vesting period is 4 years

Phone: Employees get free phones (latest devices) with Voice & Data plans 

Home Office:  DSL/Cable Internet subsidized.

Off-site Fitness Reimbursement upto 250$ per year

Flexible work schedules:  I have worked remote (vpn, mobile vpn) out of the town.

Good Health Benefits:
cons: Base Salary is typically less and yearly increase percentages dismal in the US.

review_title: Good company name for your resume
job_title: Research and Development Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
- HMO is the best. this is the only reason I'm staying here
- free gym (but I don't use it)
- flexible time but depends on your team. some teams have fix schedules
cons:
- office politics
- engineers are promoted to managers even though they don't fit the role
- salary in not competitive. they keep giving excuse of they are "above average" compare to other companies
- every small annual salary increase. sometimes you even get none (specially if you're not in good terms with your manager)
- no formal training when put in a new project
- some managers don't know what they are doing
- work-life balance is a lie
- they expect their people to be outspoken and outgoing. if you are not a social person, then don't expect any promotions

review_title: Good company, Good people. A great place to work.
job_title: RF Test Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Working at Nokia I've seen a lot of innovation introduced to the Mobile phone industry.  It made me proud to work there. The people are great and you can do practically anything you set your mind to.  The tricky part is getting people/teams to cooperate.  Nokia had a very relaxed personal time policy.  Very few "hard butts" or "j-erks" in management overall in the San Diego site.   A very good experience for 11 years.
cons:
RE-org's happened at least once a year.  Mandatory work tools changed about the same frequency.  Few projects came completely out of San Diego, most were collaborations with Finland teams.  Bonuses were like an oasis in the desert.  They were also based on un-achievable goals.  
Being absorbed by Microsoft  is/was a nightmare.

review_title: Company values shapes the employees attitude
job_title: Social Media Specialist in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: Nokia is a company that allow their employees to grow their personal and career development. From the moment you get hired, you can trust there are many fields of action, were you could move in case you want to improve or change your career path. On the other hand the HR organization makes sure to offer enough tools and resources in order to support their employees personal improvement. We also have colleagues with coaching background willing to support us in case we are dealing with professional or personal issues.
cons: I find Nokia a very dynamic company in terms of processes, this to me is actually a pro, but I understand not every person is made to work in a company that constantly works on improving their policies, organizational structure and reinnovating their portfolio.

review_title: Well balanced work-life ratio, great culture, low salary
pros:
Mostly correct expectations for work load, depends on actual team and area.
Well regulated benefits, professional internal processes. Preferred self-sufficiency and given results instead of micro-mgmt and workhour accounting.
cons:
None to insignificant salary increase, very soon becomes below market average in recent environment.
No loyalty to decent working employees also when making decisions about job transfers to other sites.

review_title: Good company, should not be a kannada company
pros:
1. Work life balance
2. Take home is good 
3. Lot of benefits with tax on high level 
4. Less HR involvement 
5. Lot of in house development projects
6. Lot of employee engagement activities
cons:
1. Lack of energy in the team 
2. Lot of older married people. Old ethics, 
3. Kannada is official language in Bangalore office. I have seen technical discussions in Kannada. 
4. Kannada Politics is high
5. Bad food
6. Bad Canteen 
7. Nokia went too low in cost cutting. Looks too cheap for a product base company like nokia
8. Worst appraisal cycle. After evaluation it takes a year to reflect that in your salary. 
9. Employee engagement activities are paid and conducted by empolyees only which tends to be very silly like school events

review_title: Nokia used to a be a good place to work at, not so much now
pros: New cloud technologies, lot of challenges, flexible working hours, free coffee and tea.
cons: Employees are no longer respected, people are treated as disposable resources, thrown from one team to another more and more often. Project deadlines are getting shorter and shorter while people are leaving, this puts even more pressure on those that remain. Outlook of the whole telecom industry is not so good nowadays. After 7-8 years when you reach job grade 9 and you don't want to give up on programming you have absolutely no way to further develop and/or get any raise. People become too specialized in a field and have no means to get out. Best to leave between 3-6 years, otherwise you will get burnt out.

pros: Best company whose heart and vision were in the right direction. Flexible hours, open to ideas and genuinely concerned about customers.
cons: Being on the West Coast of the US meant many days of 5:00 am calls to Finland. A mobile giant that doesn't understand the US market and refuses to let the US unit operate how it needs to. Too many levels of management. Slow to move on good ideas. Poor execution. New US management team has many gifted leaders but the marketing department is careless and out of touch with the company's brand situation.

review_title: I learned a lot when working in Nokia
pros: Nokia is a fine company with great culture, good managers and colleagues, talented engineers, lots of option for career opportunity and ok salary.  I had worked in Nokia for over 17 years and I am proud of my contribution to the company, happy with what I learned and experienced there.
cons: Comparing to my early days in Nokia,  I feel that it's getting too risk-averse, bureaucratic, and slow in decision making - typical big-company problems.  One thing I personally feel as a failure of Nokia was its attitude towards consumers, developers and suppliers during its heydays.  The company (including me) at that time were too arrogant to its partners, and believed too much of its own power or capability to 'shape the market' and 'lead the consumers' instead of humbly listen to them and truly care them.  The attitude certainly has changed now and I hope it's not too late.

review_title: Generally good, sometimes subject to tunnel vision
pros: I left Nokia in 2007. It was generally a good place to work. Very good benefits, competitive salaries, good work/life balance. Many of the individual contributors are very smart, hard-working people. The problems are interesting, and global, and there are usually a few trips to somewhere interesting (if you think Finland is interesting).
cons: The middle management is the weak link. The top guys usually get it, but there's a long game of telephone and pass-the-buck so by the time it gets to the lower level middle managers, sometimes the big picture can be missed. The bonus program can also put people very at odds with each other, competing to check their checkboxes rather than actually think.

review_title: Learnt a lot, but wish management was more proactive in making tough changes.
pros:
1. Exposure to some very talented people
2. Strong work ethic
3. Strong emphasis on environmental awareness and responsibility
4. Never a dull moment, keeps you on your toes
5. New management seems to know what they are doing...
cons:
1. Management waited too long to right the sinking Symbian ship
2. Upper management allowed too many mid-level 'empire builders' to take over and further their own agendas, at the expense of the company
3. Too many re-orgs, way too frequently -- destroys employee morale
4. Ad-hoc appointments of some managers, without proper due diligence
5. Arrogance and Euro-centric thinking on the part of prior upper management; still evident even with new managers, especially in Finland

review_title: Excellent place to work.   A bit worried about the future.
pros: Culture is great.  Work/Life balance is very well respected at all levels of management.   Genuine caring by upper management for its people.    Opportunity to work with other cultures is very much encouraged and necessary to be successful.    Good environment in the office.   Encouragement to work remotely as long as appropriate for the role.    Company culture is very diverse.
cons: Clhallenging to meet schedules and deliver on time.    Quality is not where it used to be.  Too much focus on technology for the sake of technology instead of to meet market demands.  A bit behind on technology (touch and qwerty) that is now in the market in full force.

pros:
- Great salary and benefits as an expatriate senior manager
- Good pedigree in the tech/IT industry based on the Nokia name
- Exposure to international offices and contacts
cons:
- Limited to 'kissing ass' or a 'cover your ass' culture of working
- Reduction in R&D is a death-knell for the brand's innovation
- Incompetent hiring for local senior managers is killing team morale and passion
- Expats are subject to lop-sided local employment policies. Do your homework before you sign up.
- Reorgs happen all the time, and staff are left wondering what the true intentions are. Stinks of a COVER UP!!

review_title: Overall a good place to learn lots of things technically as well as see how company works in such vibrant competition.
pros:
1. Work/Life balance is very good.
2. As organization is very very big....lots of things goes around and person with passion can find people doing various things.
3. Ample time to try out things and experiment more.
4. Management is supporting and recognize your hard work.
cons:
1. In recent times, top level decisions have turned out to be destructive in terms of implementation which lowers employee morale.
2. Projects often misses the deadline which results in bonus compensation.
3. Often implementing the things which has come to market already resulting in loss of market share.
4. Too much R&D for certain modules and at later point of time...cancellation of project or cancellation of product turns employee work into waste.

pros:
Hands on experience. Your thrown right into the fire. 
It has good balance between work and family. 
Flexible hours
Overall the employees are smart and talented people that are great to work with.
cons:
-Re-orgs every 6 months keeping employees wondering all time
-Not a lot of growth and opportunity to work on new stuff.  
-Raises are not given annually or during review time even w/great reviews. 
-Continually changing company direction;  the future looks uncertain - it is not clear whether the company will be able to reclaim leadership. It is not clear what new products/ideas will be game changer. 
-Decisions take forever to be made which also affects innovation and creativity among employees.

review_title: Nokia was a fantastic company to work for with plenty of talented people and great work.
pros: The organization was always quite flat so not too many chiefs, there was always a steady stream of new projects and opportunities to learn new skills. Another positive was the corporate culture. We were a cohesive and collaborative tribe for many years and we had the freedom to grow within the company.
cons: Many times, the organization moved too slow and just about the time great work was put in place, we'd change direction or start reinventing the wheel. Lastly, the downsizing, layoffs, redundecies, renewals, refocusing, etc etc was neverending.

pros:
-Salary and Benefits offer are somehow above average [depends on the position].
-Work environment are well balance and harmonious.
-Business Ethics is being practice somehow.
cons:
-Scope of work and functions violates the Employment contract.
-Career growth [Job Grade] is very slow without someone backing you out, despite they know you are a candidate.
-Taking advantage of what you are capable of and assigning you in one position without proper transfer or growth employment package.
-Benefits always put on hold/cancelled/manipulated [e.g. buying of new laptap, mobile, Travels, Company events.].
-The employment package you have from the beginning is a great battle before it change or acknowledge with actions.

review_title: good place to start professional career in the industry, not worth staying for longer run
pros:
great place to start career after graduating
tons of useful telco knowledge available to learn and master
good and fun atmosphere as 90% of employees are aged 25-30yrs
possibility of business trips
cons:
low cost location - Poland - low salaries comparing to Western Europe
almost no real chances of advancement as an engineer
no real salary increase over years of work and experience
employees are aged 25-30yrs ? (everybody leaves after 4-5 years or even sooner)
totally bored and disgusted with constant low cost policy
constant organisation changes
some people and departments doesn't really feel responisble for product final quality which causes other depts to suffer
horrible IT, working here on 4 years laptop is normal, wasting so much time due to crappy and old hardware, seems like spending 1000$ for an up to date laptop is not worth even though if it could speed up working by 40% and cause less employee frustration

pros: When Nokia went well, working there was really exciting. You could do things, you were listened to and the ratio "despicable person"/employee was very low. Nowadays things have gone so bad that there is a serious opportunity to be part of a great turnaround ... provided you can make it happen. The trouble is that the "despicable person"/employee ratio as rocketed following the redundancies and it has not come down back to normal levels yet.
cons: Still too many senior managers who mistake illusion for vision and think it makes them look smart. Some of them have paid the price for it, but not all of them. I also think that the focus of maps & navigation is misplaced, not to mention the fact that the offering does not measure up to the main competitor in fundamental areas.

review_title: Great multi-national company, but LOOK before you leap to an offer in India
pros:
NSN is at the fore-front of technology and offers great experience in mobile broadband and services. Fantastic opportunity to work on projects for leading service providers globally, interacting with dynamic and passionate team.  It is truly a multi-national company with well defined values and career development process as well as tools to support work-life balance.

India is a strategic location for NSN and hosts key senior management roles.
cons:
Leadership in India do not show enough commitment to NSN values which could result in a disappointing experience for employees.  As an expat (or "local plus" employee), you either lower your expectations substantially or find another location to work with NSN beside India.
Company is going through transformation currently, career opportunity may not be great in short/medium time-frame.

pros:
The best thing in Nokia is the culture. It's open and transparent. There are no hierarchies. There is a strong ethos for doing good and being a good corporate citizen. 

People typically cooperate well,  there are no silos or unnecessary secrecy. It's an employer one can respect and a company which respects you as well.  

It has been a truly global company as well.  Important things are done and decisions made across the world. People are used to working across time zones.
cons: During the recent years Nokia has been in great trouble.  As the business has been shrinking and there have been layoffs, the company has lost many good people and the environment has been very challenging for those who stayed.  However,  my experience has been that the company treats people respectfully even in difficult situations.

pros:
- putting a lot of effort in state-of-the-art techniques of writing better code (clean code, agile methodologies, focus on testing etc.)
- a lot of possibilities to develop your skills - good training schemes
- changes to evolve inside the company
- good working environment - I liked spending time at work
- very good benefit package as for Poland
cons: - the size of the company was sometimes overwhelming (like it was super hard to get a RAM increase or a SSD drive in order to work faster on the code, because of so much layers)

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Opportunity to work with varied people and talent.
They try to attain good talent.
They reward at a personal level and tie it to overall company health.
They have a learning culture.
They are making good steps in driving more accountability at the personal level.
cons:
Recent misteps in the industry has lead to bad decisions and a huge reduction of workforce. They think this is the only to growth which is wrong.
they don't listen to the people enough.
They tend to promote before a person is ready for the role.
A little too prideful in the corporate culture and this is leading to big mistakes.

review_title: Great company that treats employees well
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Alpharetta, GA
pros: Nokia is a great company to work for as a technical engineer as there is a high level of technical competence across all areas of the company.  The hours are flexible as needed and my colleagues are generally fantastic.  The pay is generally average to above average, but other benefits such as 401k match and paid time off are exceptional.  Even in the unfortunate situation where the company needs to lay people off, they are treated fairly, and the company makes the transition as painless as possible for the departing employee.
cons: When the company is not doing well it is reflected by doing layoffs.  When the company is doing well, they tend to hire like crazy.  This results in a viscous repetitive cycle of too aggressive hiring followed by layoffs followed by more hiring followed by more layoffs.  This is not helpful for overall employee morale.

pros: Flexible timings. Flexibility to move to different teams is possible but not easy.
cons:
NSN as a company is great to work with BUT...............
NSN Bangalore Office -
To much of regionalism & favoritism. Managers give preference to people from there natives/states. HR has no say. Managers have all the power to decide the fate of employees. Although English is the official language of communication but except English all regional languages are used, even when others don't understand. 
Higher management in Bangalore office consist of people who have been there since many years almost 12+. All of them have their own comfort areas & circle of people. 
Recruitment is also region specific. Since last 4 years I have seen majority of freshers recruitment is only from one state. Recruitment never happens from north.
There is a wide disparity among salaries & job grade of equal experience people having similar caliber. 
Only way of survival is either be a individual performer (& don't care about money & grade) or make friends with management. 
If a person is lucky he/she may find a good manager.

job_title: R&D Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
A lot benefits applicable on day 1 even for probationary employees
Phone benefits that are like a sign up perk even for probationary employees
Being paid in advance of work done.
Vision and Medicines reimbursement benefits that are both flexible and substantial
Vast amount of access to training for professional and personal development both as part of official functions or not
Lateral moves are a possibility within the organization
Working with the best talent also helps in encouraging to always be at my best
Cool makerspace for innovation
High level of trust for employees and does not do timekeeping.
You are trained for a high level of work ethic and values and are expected to live it in the work place.
A high regard for safety of each employee, contractor or customer.
cons: They demand the best and won't settle for mediocrity

review_title: Best benefit package and fun company culture
pros:
-High HMO limit for employee and unlimited number of dependents meeting the criteria
-Medicine and vision reimbursement
-Dental package
-Flexible time (no time in, time out)
-No dresscode
-Output oriented
-No micromanaging
-Spacious workspace
-Culture is nice- employees are friendly (not all but most)

Even the HR of another company was surprised with the health benefit package of Nokia. He/she said it was his/her the first time encountering that kind of benefit.
cons:
-Not much opportunity for growth or at least in the team I belong to
-Not so competitive base pay 
-It could sometimes get so stressful especially when release date is nearing- OT needs to be rendered even on weekends
-Not enough mentorship from line managers

job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros:
As most functions in the company don't demand high effort you can try to spare time for personal training which will be very valuable if you intend to leave the company.
Also it's still better than being unemployed.
cons: The NSN portuguese global center exists to remotely execute projects and tasks with low skills requirements which you can define as "monkey" work. Interesting work is still done on local sites. The global center based in Portugal is in consequence a pure low-cost center. This explains why skilled people are leaving NSN Portugal. Actually many of them are even leaving the country.

review_title: Telecom industry is not a sunrise industry, but won't be sunset
job_title: Software Test Engineer in New Providence, NJ
pros:
1. Great engineer company, unlike some small companies where the managers dominate. In Nokia, the engineers are the key values.
2. Many senior employees are at retired age, there is more opportunities for young engineers actually.
3. Good benefits, not that much push from management
4. With 5G coming out, Nokia has a chance to be back on the stage. If you join now, maybe there is something you can expect in the near future
cons:
1. If you like the city life, it might not be a good idea to work in Nokia. 
2. Many colleagues are senior engineers, not just their levels, I mean the age. No offense, you can learn a lot from them about telecom knowledge, but it means there won't be that many company events, cause most of them are not that age.
3. Lunch is boring

review_title: A company with a multitude of interesting technical career possibilities, but also career risks due to frequent layoffs.
pros: - If you are e.g. a technical R & D person and love that kind of work, there are many kinds of interesting projects available.
cons: - The layoffs in general and especially after mergers can ruin your career. The products sold are big in size, and require a lot of personnel to build. Therefore, when the personnel is every now and then reduced, you have very little chances of continuing e.g. as an entrepreneur in the same business, but you may be forced to start your career all over, especially if you have been a R&D person.

job_title: Research and Development Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: I like to work here because of the relaxed culture. This organization seeks to be as flat as possible therefore your voices and grievances can be heard.
cons: It really depends on the manager. Unfortunately, some managers put more focus on quantity versus quality. Sacrificing quality leads to a lot of bugs.. And frankly, this company seems to be gravitating towards a bug driven development. Processes that were put in place to prevent such insidents from happening are not being followed when there are tight deadlines. But.... No matter how much emphasis you put on your delivery, when there is no quality, bugs will always creep out.

review_title: What's it like to work in Nokia Beijing
pros:
1. A maximum of 30 days Vacation 
2. elastic work time,  9:00 ~6:00,  well planned development  reduced OT.
