3. Rich experienced management team, can get a lot of support to team member
4. highly transparent, no simple people relationship.
5. Global working environment, to work with people from all around the world.
6. Technology leadership in industry trend, cloud native and devops lead.
7. Annual salary increase and bonus based on performance.
8. Superb work environment with air cleaner ensure office PM2.5 below 20.
9. plenty of activities provide by the laber union
cons:
Compared with some internet internet company,  salary is lower,  while  work load and pressure are as low as well.
Not allowed to take pet in office.

pros: I you can get over the always changing deadlines, incompetent managers, yearly restructuralization then it is an OK place. You won't be a billionaire, but the salaries are not that bad. The workload can be anywhere from non-existent to constant overtime based on the product/project. There is a sauna, gym in the building and free garage on a first came - first served basis.
cons: Competence development is not really forced, I mean if you are only doing your daily job you can't learn a lot, this is because ancient telco technologies, BUT job rotation is a thing to be fair. Gym is not free any more. Lots of good people left the company in the last years. The company has an internal saying "quality first", but unfortunately only engineers are trying to do so...

job_title: Project Team Lead in Athens, Attica
pros: Friendly, easy-going environment, lots of knowledgeable people to learn from, lots of internal training opportunities.
cons: Company values are just words on paper when it comes to massive lay offs, and these come very often. So you can get out of job overnight, without notice, without doing anything wrong and without being given the opportunity to react and keep your job. The more people who know, the more likely you are to progress and survive, otherwise, walk on your toes all the time, because you may be the next to be fired.

review_title: Good place for process oriented consultants and managers
pros:
Good work life balance
Good monetary benefits in terms of variable pay and other allowances
Handset and laptop will be provided to you within your first day of joining and you can take it with you even leave the organization after some specific period
Transparency about management decisions
cons:
No technical career growth. If you are really want to grow technically then this is not your place
Reorganization happens every six months 
You will be hired for some core technical competencies and they ask to you work for process and project management area
Services are not best in the market standards. You're far behind than your competitors
Decommissioning almost 4 services within a year because of poor acquisitions  
Salaries are not up to the market standards
Too many people working on a same project

review_title: Pay and benefits are good, but first/mid management make poor decisions.
pros:
Great people and great team spirit in the individual teams.
Excellent salary.
Really good benefits and 401K match.
Not too much internal politics any more, now that Symbian and Meego are dead.
cons:
The managers are not experienced or trained well, and many managers lack any people skills.  The good managers are the ones who were trained elsewhere, not the ones that are home-grown.
Do not expect much formal training; most of that was cut a couple of years ago.
There is not much internal communication about strategy or successes/failures; you may not hear from your Director for many months.

job_title: Enb Integration and Verification Engineer in Irving, TX
pros: Work is not stressful. The learning opportunities here are really great. They provide good training and there are good opportunities for advancement and visibility to other teams. Of course it depends upon the team you are in and the manager. But, on a general note the work lifestyle here is pretty good and there are veterans and excellent talent around. They also have nice benefits like 401k matching, good vacation accruals, very good health insurance plans to choose from, etc.
cons: Vacation carryover was cut about the time I left. The HR policy on Green Card sponsorship category is placed at EB3 and EB2 is allowed only for manager positions. This could have been better. Also, the annual compensation was very low for a mid-senior level engineer. I heard salaries increased after many people left. These are things they could work on. Other than that, there isn't anything bad about this place.

pros: Nokia is very unique in its culture. Despite going through many transformations and way too many changes, remained to be very humane in its approach, provides ultimate flexibility to its employees for managing work, incredibly respectful for individuals especially on private life, health etc matters, always thrives to make things better.
cons: Working in Nokia can be tiring for those who can not keep up with extremely fast pace of change. All changes; brand, strategy, organization, etc all the time which is annoying. Compensation & benefits is just going worse each day, Nokia is no longer a competitive employer for remuneration.

pros: They were flexible with the time table and the benefits were good (example of benefits: 24 day vacation, health insurance, sport, a sum allocated each year for glasses, yearly bonuses, Christmas bonus) . The teams were usually friendly and they kept an appearance of a pleasant collaboration.
cons: Not a good environment for growth, usually keep doing the same thing over and over again. Not really a good learning place. The salary will increase slowly and will be a slight variation of the first negation throughout time. The environment was toxic, and mostly people were not highly skilled. The lack of motivation was something common among employees. The salaries were not small, but not great either, it was just enough to keep you.

pros:
Free beer cooler in break room.
Euro-owned company benefits in the realm of vacation, pension, make this a great place to work and grow if the environment is right.
cons:
-They're downsizing Austin, moving to Dallas and Naperville (IL).  This sets the tone for treatment and culture.
-IT "management" is clueless in two realms: technology, and people management.
-IT Infrastructure vision is completely driven by software engineering group, leading to antiquated technologies, just-keep-the-lights-on vision, and poor morale across the board.
-no tiering of skillsets and experience.  If you were hired on as an anesthesiologist, they'd expect you to mop the floor before you leave for the day, and think that's good resource management.
-zero training plan or budget
-no retention efforts.  
-how many tickets have you closed today?

review_title: Clarify your message.  It feels that you yourself don't fully believe what you saying.
job_title: Team Leader in Helsinki, Western Finland
pros: Working with high volume products.  This gives great motivation to external suppliers to start new project developments with Nokia.  Vendors come to you, and not the other way around.
cons: The R&D side of Nokia is highly focused on Finland.  While I wouldn't say that there is a glass-ceiling for non-Finns as such, not being able to speak Finnish makes you somewhat of an outsider.  You have to make an extra effort if you want to get ahead as a foreigner.  Also, if you are not based in Finland, the situation can be very difficult.  From persons I have spoken with who are based in e.g. Denmark, Germany, and in the US, there is a lot of resentment against the "Finnish mafia."

review_title: Good People.  Executive Management Seems Lost.  Many Fiefdoms.
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Open and encouraging culture.  Lots of opportunities to participate and be involved.  Socialization and collaboration are rewarded.  Great opportunity to broaden horizons.  If there is something you can think about in mobile chances are that Nokia has two teams working on it.  Pay and benefits are good as well.
cons: The Pros have lead to management abuse in certain areas.  While the company is open they also tend to avoid conflict and avoid fixing issues in the management chain.  This allows certain managers, who choose to take advantage of the openness within the company, to run rampant.  Stated Nokia culture values have been abused, but not dealt with.  If you land in a bad team you are doomed.

pros:
1. Work life balance is well supported by organization.
2. The organization is focussed in its approach and always carries out innovation at its best.
3. The organization values its employees and offers a great deal of opportunity for them.
4. The compensation structure is great compared to a lot of other telecom organizations.
5. The leadership team in India and Globally have led the organization to greater heights even in times of adversity.
cons:
1. The organization need to focus on the next generation wave in technology & telecom and get the right people for right job.
2. Try to create a workplace culture than can adopt and help people grow as individuals and as team.
3. Lack of consistency in the salaries offered to similar individuals in the organziation.

review_title: The Rise & Fall of Nokia Mobile
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Makati City
pros: NMP had an open culture, supported autonomy learn by doing, teamwork, taking calculated risks and had very strong focus on values, human resource/career development and was very transparent, even when times got tough.
cons: Sadly despite the openness and "flatness" and leanness of the organization, a rift developed between the Board and the market trends. Despite its market leadership and pioneering advantage, Nokia focused on hardware even when the market was looking for platforms or mobile ecosystems that would really bring the internet into the phone. Thus despite its tepid catch up efforts via the OVI platform, iOS & Android quickly kicked Nokia aside.

job_title: Research and Development Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Good place to settle down. 
Senior people can take work from home as much as they want.
Work pressure is less.
Its all good if you want to focus on your pesona life.
cons:
No so good for folks who are growing in their career. Salary growth is less. Less opportunity to learn new things. Senior people don't have the time or are not interested to to do something challenging which is good for them but bad for you. 
If you plan to join Nokia then join late and settle down.

review_title: It's an old boy network and there's a ton of dead weight
pros: The pay is OK, and it is a place where you can get started in the mobile industry then move on.
cons: It's an old boy network, and if you have the right friends you'll go far.  But if you don't, then you won't like it here.   In my team there were more "product management" and "marketing" people than engineers.  These folks worked minimal hours, they came in at 10, took a long lunch, and then they left at 4.  On Friday they were all "working from home".   They would jet around the world and talk to other people about the projects I was working on, but since they didn't talk to me I never knew what these folks were up to.   I watched as some of the most incompetant of the bunch got promoted to managers.

review_title: Great place to work unil 2009, then just a waste of time
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Boston, MA
pros: A company that once had great values and an inspiring working environment.
cons: Until the end of 2009 Nokia was an exciting and inspiring place to work in. People were passionate about their jobs. But then the iPhone market disruption kicked in and the management kept ignoring it. As a result profits and sales volumes fell. Reorgs were constant, people were treated bad and nobody did any work whatsoever, people waited for things to get in order again and normal work to resume. Then came new CEO Elop who dropped the bomb and the company was in a downward spiral until sold for peanuts. All was lost. A shame.

pros:
Calm, peaceful. We are treated with dignity and trust. Excellent work-life balance.
Perfect place, if you prefer stability and status quo, and just wanna work somewhere without further career, learning or self development ambitions.
cons:
Average salary and benefits. Innovation ideas pressure on developers and testers is counterproductive. Experienced developers are let to go away easily for a better pay, or pushed to leave technical role for management career path. Management push focus to business but strongly neglect technology side. 
Legacy development tools and methods: software design does not keep the pace with modern disciplines, products are based on legacy, hardly maintainable spaghetti code, and such custom testing tools, with which you may not gain any useful knowledge of technologies anywhere, but only in Nokia

review_title: Not a bad place to work at all, just somewhat conservative and slow to adapt to change
job_title: Software Design Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Sound and conservative management
- Pleasant place to work, people tend to be very friendly
- Benefits and vacation time are generous
- Get to work with a large company with global prestige
- Rich company can afford paying for little things here in there (like HD video conferencing) that are sound and helpful but not extravagant
cons:
- Management might be too slow to innovate and adapt to change
- Tough to get promotions without moving to Europe or another country
- Lots of red tape involved in getting anything done, needs to have more entrepreneurial attitude

review_title: A company in a tough situation but with excellent products, great people, and total commitment to success.
pros: A long track record of designing and manufacturing high quality products, with a renewed emphasis on groundbreaking innovation and style.   A very mature manufacturing and distribution infrastructure with global reach.   The new strategic partnership with Microsoft, enabling a suite of future customer experiences spanning business and personal scenerios.  Excellent support of the employees in terms of remuneration, benefits and the overally working environment.
cons: Current market position relative to the competition from Apple, Samsung, and Google.   Relative immaturity of some internal operational systems and teams.   Uncertainty in terms of revenue and growth of the company's value.

review_title: Great memories and amazing colleagues. Good company to work for especially in it's heyday.
pros:
Nokia has a great company culture.
Nokia is a truly global company and there are plenty of possibilities for anyone to transfer internationally. 
Frequent travel required sometimes to exotic destinations. 
Flexibility and good work-life balance. Ability to work from home when necessary.
Compensation tied to performance with 6 month reviews.
Health insurance included
cons:
Re-organisation became so frequent that we almost expected it every year. It also created disruption and left many employees hanging in limbo waiting for information.
Bonus targets were often set very high.
Working for a global company sometimes meant unsociable hours video or teleconferencing with colleagues in other countries particularly 3 way conference across multiple time zones.

review_title: Fun work environment, not so fun work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: The work environment has been fun and relaxed. They're really trying hard to make the Agile thing work, and management is fortunately on board with it. We get nice perks like free fruit daily and sometimes free lunches. Also the occasional sponsored happy hour. Engineers have plenty of opportunities to be heard and make a difference.
cons: The company's uncertain future makes many people uneasy. The group I've worked with in Chicago isn't exactly working with the worlds latest technologies, which can be frustrating. Some projects have been more fun than others. While management is pushing for Agile, they're unable to deal with certain engineers that are pretty against it.

pros:
Nokia had nice people across most of the business who were trying hard to get through. 
At the time it was one of the biggest technology companies to work for.
Could set up a good work/life balance
cons:
Silos everywhere
Over focus on getting "bonus" - to the point of negatively impacting hundreds of people in their ability to do simple tasks just to get a senior manager their bonus (the change was then fixed over the next six months - because like who cares about build times for developers!)
Reorganisation Hell - 8 reorgs in 4 years - you reach the "if I sit and do as little as possible it'll change soon" state
"Bonus" expectations set so low that you could only fail if asked to limbo under them - doing minimum work for 3 months and still scored "outstanding"?!?

review_title: Great company to work, amazing peers and lots of learning
pros: I have been with the company for about 5 years and enjoying my journey till date. The Product that I'm working on has a very fast-paced development and testing cycle. So, there's a lot of work and new learning all the time. You can always ask for a change OR more responsibilities. Being proactive in taking multiple projects OR doing beyond what you are expected to do is very much appreciated and encouraged by the management. Subordinates/Immediate peers are very friendly and supportive. Team Leads, Managers, and even Directors and Vice Presidents are very approachable.
cons:
Nokia is into challenging market and has though competition.
Base pay is decent, but the additional compensation/benefits are not great.

pros: Can be a good place to gain some experience.  Compensation and benefits can be better than  the competition in mature markets.
cons:
Organization is biased in favor of young white, northern European males, particularly those from Finland and to a lessor degree from Germany.  Job requirements as well as performance measures are not applied to this group.  

Likewise product development is very Euro-centric, presenting problems for implementation elsewhere. 

There is almost no real skill in services management.  Project and program management are extremely immature.  

Few standard objective measures set by management.  

There has been a criminal investigation of corruption and wrong doing in the ex-Siemens operations.  There continue to be struggles with anti-corruption and ethics.  

It is a company of administrators, not leaders.

review_title: For past 4 years, I had worked in NSN, and want to rate it as my best experience so far in life.
job_title: MBB Core Engineer in Islamabad, Islamabad
pros: NSN is a wonderful, dynamic and challenging organization. I have learned a great deal in my current job role because of the training culture in the organization, senior's support and with the on the job training.
cons: In the past, I have seen conflicts in Resource and Project management, which affects the overall work flow and ultimately resources involved in the project are also demoralized and downgraded. Although, it was past, and currently there is a huge improvement seen in this sector.

review_title: Generally a very good company that treats employees well.
pros: Has been a terrific company to work for- great benefits and much care about individuals.  Very forward thinking about technology and socially active internally.  It is also the most ethical company I have ever worked for.
cons: Economic challenges as they move forward with a new OS.  Also it is losing some (much) of that Finnish nature that has served it so well from a human-relations perspective (I know very few people that actually quit Nokia- rather they got reluctantly laid off).

pros: At Nokia you can truly be yourself. You are encouraged to question old habits and ways of working, and also to share the good and positive ways of working so that others can learn and possibly adapt them too. Most of the people are passionate about what they are doing and what the company is doing and they are great to work with.
cons: It's not always easy to advance in your career even if you wish so. People tend to stay in their position until they're fired or they decide to look for new opportunities outside of Nokia

review_title: Nokia doesn't care about it's top performers
pros: Good salary and benefits and company is flexible as far as work hours, etc. AH location is OK, remodeled offices are a little better than they used to be.
cons: All decisions are made by senior managers without any input from lower level managers/employees. Left hand doesn't know what right hand is doing, layoffs upon layoffs occur regardless of quarterly results and directed by senior management regardless if you worked very hard to be a top performing employee. No one in the organization (at least in US) has passion for the work as there's no motivation to.

review_title: Good company, but not the Kraków which is a low cost center
pros:
- steady job
- a lot of things to do - but not especially challenging if you end up in a wrong project
- money is always on time
cons:
Kraków location is a low cost center with all its disadvantages:
- a lot of people are leaving the company because of:
- low salaries (comparing to the market in Kraków)
- student driven development (because of the reasons mentioned above)
- managers who do not fit their roles
- used up office space
- second building across town (!) only because it is the cheapest offering possible
- new chairs (Wrocław center was disposing their old ones so we got them )

review_title: Many growing segments of Telecom and IOT
job_title: Applications and Analytics in Naperville, IL
pros:
After the purchase of Alcatel-Lucent the portfolio is really loaded giving Nokia a great chance to take market lead in several segments
Salary and benefits are among the best
cons:
After the purchase of Alcatel-Lucent there have been many decisions for what to keep in the portfolio and the staff numbers of the combined companies. This is being done as thoughtfully as possible. However this is still a cause of stress for many.
There may be frequent changes to portfolio and staff for the next year or two.

review_title: A good place to work, with strong management and career possibilities
pros: Nokia is an innovative company, with a good reputation and standing. I am constantly being given greater responsibility, and I feel that Nokia will support my career progression. In my position, I am always exposed to interesting new technologies, and I feel like i am helping the world progress. Managements attitudes to staff, certainly at a professional level, are very good, and I feel that I am listened to if I have problems. They are also very flexible, and accomodating to an individuals personal needs
cons: communication is often quite poor, and the method used to calculate bonuses is a bit arbitrary. There is also quite a lot of unneccessary travel to meetings, which could be much more efficient.

review_title: It was my dream job but was forced to leave due to the shifts and the location of the client place
pros:
I was interested working for the company as it was basically a telecom company. 
It provided lots of job satisfaction to me personally and professionally.
I was contented with my pay and other benefits as doing such a work more important than getting the pay.
cons: My company met to my aspirations perfectly all the time but being only one female member in my team and due to the workplace being situated in a remote place unwillingness to come in afternoon and night shifts made me leave the company

pros:
* Best Environment to learn the cutting edge Service Provider Technlogies.
* Flexible envirionment, where in you can ask for varied types of work like Creating HLD Solution, Working on Caveat cases of troubleshooting, Creating New Configuration for Integrating new services into network.
* Work Life balance.
Your body gets sufficient time to exercise and remain healthy forever.
cons:
* Bad in company facilities.
    The Coffee and tea quality and hot-drink options are bad.
    If a toilet has some problem, it will take ages for it to get repaired.
    The handwash in the toilet is never ever refilled once empty, only water is refilled into it.

These things have been observed in Nokia Solutions & Networks, Mumbai Powai office.

job_title: Chief Executive Officer Speechwriter in Boulder, CO
pros: Nokia is making the transition from a hardware to software company.  It is moving into the world of IoT, AI and Robotics as they apply to all aspects of areas such as digital health, virtual reality and the forces driving the fourth industrial revolution.  Nokia Bell Labs and Nokia Technologies are the innovation powerhouses driving this transformation.
cons: The company is working hard to drive a new cultural foundation and it bumping into the typical issues of top down idealism meeting the hard realities of bottom up execution.   Nokia wants to move from its dependence on communications service providers and their ups and downs of capital investment to fill the gaps with vertical industries.  It has a gap of knowledge here and it has been slow going.

pros: Bell-Labs used to be part of Alcatel-Lucent, and was one of several assets which attracted NOKIA to buy the whole company (at least thats the story they tell). There are still a lot of great people, innovators and experts around here. So it might be an interesting place to work for a limited time.
cons: Constant management rotation. Each new head wants to optimise and cut costs, so working conditions are never converging towards a reliable state. Managment likes tools, 'processes' and automation, so we have a lot of this. No interest to adapt to real needs. No clear reason why, but every employee has to handle this stuff individually, which causes a lot of friction losses.  So instead of doing research, you try to figure out how to handle these tools or who is responsible, who might be the contact for a problem etc.

review_title: Not a great company to work for if you want career progression
pros: The only pro's I can think of is that they offer a decent benefits package. Pension, healthcare, mobile phone, flexible working hours. i.e. you have to work between 9:30-12:00 and 14:00-16:00, but you can work what you want other than that so long as you do your 37.5 hours a week. They also offer a good bonus scheme (although this has declined in recent years)
cons:
Software Engineers are not treated well at the company.
They are paid less than other departments such as marketing.
There is no room for career progression. I am stuck on the same grade since I started the company even though in all my performance reviews I have exceeding all my targets.
Getting professional training is difficult, as the company budgets are too restrictive.

review_title: You would have to be desperate to join this company now-survival in question
pros: Once a real power house but the world has changed and it has been left in the dust.
cons: OK tech is cyclical but you do expect a company that once had respect as a core value would treat people accordingly. No longer. Although I left a long time ago it saddens me to hear all the stories of HR breaking agreements with employees and suggesting a legal avenue to resolve them, of people who relocated thousands of miles for the company being told to leave at very short notice (less than a month) with impacts on family and other examples of borderline behavior. Why would you join a company that treats people like this?

review_title: It use to be a great place to work
pros: If senior management start to listen there still might be some hope. It use to be one of the best companies to work for with amazing people and culture. Networking business has a great future, company just needs to find the right direction and not repeating the same mistakes over and over. The company needs to focus on people and customers, hopefully management will realize that soon.
cons: Salaries are way above business average and massive layoffs are going on, people with 11, 16, 26 years of experience doesn't matter, only cutting the cost motivates management. Treating people like sh...t will bring the company very deep.

pros: On paper, the focus is on positive goals, supportive work environment, working from home. They are branching more into consumer market.
cons:
Not sure where all the salaries are coming from, maybe I'm just a bad employee!  I don't get paid near what is listed here and as an engineer for over 15 years, I can't tell you how many years since downturn in '01 we've had "no raises and no bonuses". Maybe that was just Alcatel-Lucent and why we got bought. 
Lack of younger employees in the US. All new employees come from cheaper EU countries. 
Lack of vertical movement. 
Telecom market is shrinking (profits). 
Too few employees to do the work. 
Again, where are all these 100k+ salaries coming from?  Now I feel abused.

review_title: Offers one of the best benefit packages in the industry. Management has gone to the dogs, though.
pros:
See title. The benefits package is truly one of a kind. I've yet to join a company that beats Nokia's offerings:
- Free HMO coverage for you and unlimited number of qualified dependents
- Medicine and vision reimbursement
- Flexi-time
- Laid-back startup culture 
- Spacious workplace
cons: Some of the benefits (there used to be a free company gym) have been removed.

review_title: My best employer ever but sinking like Titanic
job_title: Global Marketing Analyst in Farnborough, England
pros:
- Very international company and everyone is treated equally
- Laid-back relaxed culture that everyone likes
- Very nice people and the senior management is easily approachable
- Fantastic work-life balance (although depends on your manager, team and role)
- Opportunity to travel around the world (if you're lucky and in the right role)
- Good pay and benefits at least in the past
cons:
- Poor performance and constant lay-offs
- The UK HQ is dominated by locals and therefore it feels more British than international 
- A lot of good people have left in the last years
- Many internal people don't anymore believe in Nokia's products although some are enthusiasts and love their Lumias
- Communication barriers between the global team and the country level organisations

review_title: Nice place to work and gain Core Networking knowledge
pros:
i) A lot to learn about core networking
ii) You will learn in and out of GSM
iii) Work - life balance is very good, manager is concerned about completing the work on time, so the given assignment you can complete in 4 hours or 12 hours, that is upon you
iv) You will be given complete responsibility for your work with minimal interference
v) Great work culture, basically you will learn in and out of core networking domain
cons:
i) You will get "only salary". Apart from that you will not get anything not even a pen
ii) No free lunch or snacks, even you have to pay for outing or team lunch from your own pocket

pros:
- truly international and mobile
- great working conditions
- loads of opportunities, countless streams, projects to support or train yourself
- secure workplace (unless you sit in a high-cost country)
- internal politics has decreased significantly
cons:
- it used to be much more agile and rapid, during the transformation it has turned to a corporate machine, hierarchy bureaucracy and everything which is a bottleneck for the nimble and bold decisions and projects
- top management has a direction, the lowest management has the same, but the middle management used to be the muddy part

pros: Good salary,Enough flexibility and freedom to learn
cons:
Be a butter chapp to your boss,otherwise he may feel bad about your behaviour.Even If you complaints to senior mgmt against your line managers in appropriate / communal  behaviour,they won't listen.They will advise you to either look in another business line or look outside "Just because he's a manager ".

Can't say about all... but there are bastards,beware! Most importantly they can harm you in your probation period as they are the one's who have to say yes/no to continue your career in Nokia...Strange but TRUE :)

review_title: Mostly good, some not so good
pros: Opportunity to see the world, work in varied fields, can job hop from function to function, better work life balance, informal culture.
cons: may become process oriented at times, some parts tend to be a bit slow when it comes to execution. Services and Software is faster compared to the rest of the org. HO in Finland which is a cold country. As Nokia is a big company, you may find bad bosses and colleagues here and there. Also the company culture varies from geography to geography and Unit to Unit. But if that do happen, there is always chance to move to another job within the company. Dont join nokia for a fat paycheque, join Nokia if you want to enjoy your work and have some time left to enjoy life.

pros: Nokia has a great work-life balance; Nokia's employees are diverse, friendly and always willing to help; Nokia provides fair compensation and excellent benefits; The location and weather in San Diego is hard to beat; It is assuring to know you are working for the top cell phone maker in the world.
cons: The main issue seems to be that our product always seems to be a step behind the competition.  For example, we are only now putting out flip, slide and full qwerty phones, while everyone else has moved on to touch screen technology.  By the time our touch screen product is out, the competition will have moved on to the next bigger and better thing.

review_title: Nokia, a great place - see you again in five years...!
pros: Good work-life balance (depending on the team and position) and relatively decent pay, flexible work hour, promotion of individual leadership, opportunity to move within the organization, free speech with people in any level
cons: Uneven quality of work among employees, too much promotion of individual leadership without clear and aligned goal setting (leading to wasted effort), random and seemingly unfair promotion of the people who are putting great effort in networking instead of working

review_title: No longer an inspiring place to work
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Beijing, Beijing
pros:
Still a band as an MNC to give a little bit merit in job market. 
Most staffs are nice. Still can be considered as a place you can reach a certain balance between life and work on some position. Maybe thank to the low efficiency. But forget to retire there.
cons:
Office politics and bureaucracy drag the foot of the company terribly. The current local management is really poor skilled and fail to encourage and inspire people. More suckers are promoted to important positions and poison the corporate culture. 
The company doesn't care the staffs and their career as before. Very sad  that once a great company now falls down to a 2nd class one.

review_title: Great company to work for, although suffered from poor leadership.
pros: Great values, culture, respect for the individual, etc. Very flexible working environment, as long as the required deliverables are met on time. Good compensation and other benefits. Plenty of opportunities to develop through training. Great teams & colleagues. A very pleasant working environment.
cons: Lack of promotional prospects, although better if you are based in Finland. Job grading scheme is a mess & does not necessarily reflect abilities. Younger 20's - 30's persons with minimal experience being promoted to senior manager roles too quickly, while some older persons with far, far greater experience are overlooked. Very poor strategy, leadership & a great deal of complacency by previous boards almost destroyed it & caused tens of thousands to lose their jobs. Should have risen to the challenge of Apple, but instead some egos got in the way!

pros:
I worked for Nokia for over 10 years. The company had a very people orientated attitude and that was reflected in the positive spirit of the people who worked there. 

There was a work hard-play-hard attitude in the team I worked for and there was always respect for work/life balance, but goals had to be achieved.
cons:
The previous senior management team made a serious number of errors, which lead to final exit of the company from mobile device manufacturing. 

Hopefully under the new leadership the company will find its Mojo again as the ethos company and what the brand stands for are very positive.

pros: Gym on the top floor.
cons:
This is a kind of red flag on a basis of giving undeserved negative job reference. 

Slandering and defaming former employees upon a background check is something, which 

a) - with a singular way of thinking - tends to sabotage the career of the employee subjected to background check

b) changes relationships with new managers in a negative direction and might result in a certain degree of isolation

c) could carry a cease and desist letter from an attorney to terminate depriving an individual of credit

d) could carry a lawsuit particularly when the information furnished in excess of the position held and the period. Information furnished beyond this, must be justified.

As for the technical matters of the position I held, it was terrible the knowledge I gained there, it's hardly compatibly to any other companies due to the integral difference of the HW architecture. And of course this is true for the other way round. 

All in all as my conclusion I do not recommend for job seekers to submit their resumes there.

review_title: Good company culture, but onboarding is not easy
pros:
- Great challenges
- A company culture that fully supports continous learning and self improvement
- Pleasant office environment
- 2 days home office per week
- Friendly and supportive colleagues
cons:
- Overcomplicated processes and miriad business softwares (so called tools) among which you can easily feel yourself completely lost
- Infinite number of abbreviations, sometimes totally unnecessarily
- Newcomers might feel a bit left alone during or after the onboarding process

job_title: Solutions Manager in Helsinki, Western Finland
pros:
Global company.  Working with different teams in different geographical regions was certainly fun.  Opportunity to travel and to meet your peers worldwide.  It was very easy (and also encouraged) to ask for help from anyone (and I mean anyone); and surely you could receive help from colleague.

Work-life balance - having strong Finnish culture, the company is extremely flexible on your work-life tradeoffs.  you can agree practically any arrangement with your line manager; and that is one of huge positive aspects.

Flat organization structure - it really helps if you can go to anyone, including very senior managers, and approach them with your problems, issues, concerns.  It is in company's culture to try to help, and back-stabbing is almost non-existent.
cons: not enough accountability for actions; relatively rigid organization

review_title: If you dont like the org structure, just stick around and in 15 minutes it will change.
job_title: Operations Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
good benefits, interesting technology
If you like working long hours, Nokia is the place for you.  The people are great, the environment and culture is good.  The company has a long history of surviving and reinventing itself over the past 140 years. Has a European feel and has much divertisty.  Management never tires of changing things every 6 months.  Good use and embracing technology
cons:
employees are expected to interact globally, no travel permitted, so you have conference calls around the clock 3am, midnight, 6pm etc
Management never tires of changing things every 6 months.  Company has a strong global brand but has failed with the US market, conserviative approach to business.

job_title: R&Amp; D Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
Lots of freedom and self management
Employee feedback driven site improvement
Initiatives on Lean and Agile
Lots of opportunities for Management roles
cons:
Small annual salary increase
Employee-HR relationships are almost always through the managers which gives managers a lot of power. Some of them abuse it.
Too much self management and freedom is very prone to abuse.
Consider office politics if you want to grow .
Not much formal trainings from outside the company.
Managers are too young. Sometimes they do not know what they are doing.

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Baku, Baku
pros: You can learn both Telecom and IT business. Nokia has lots of IT solutions on top of traditional network products compared to other telco vendors. Multinational opportunities are always available and sometime encouraged. You can combine work and travel/leisure as long as time allows. Great company to start and develop further
cons: To many mergers almost every second year. That makes people uncertain about their roles, job description and job security. Financial situation of company not in best shape as used to be 7-8 years ago. And lots pressure for very high margin sales and sometimes unrealistic targets...Keeps ending with market share loss. Chicken and egg problem.

pros:
- Work with bleeding edge technologies.
- Results of your work are used by millions of people and are changing the world.
- Friendly and inspiring atmosphere - a lot of very smart guys are around and willing to help.
- Located in the center of one of the best European cities to live in - Berlin!
- Company is helping a lot with relocation to non-German employees.
cons:
- Lack of technical competence in middle-level management and sometimes this can cause either unclear goals or even a promotion of some stupid solution just because "the boss wants it that way".
- Bureaucracy slows down some of processes.
- It's not easy to fire employees because of German laws, that's why you can find a person who is not too smart (and sometimes even harmful) but still gets a salary.

review_title: Great teamwork in a flat organization and working with in a very fun industry
pros: Completely flat organization. Considering the size of the company it's impressive how good the possibilities to drive your own ideas are. You can easily get a chance to try new areas of responsibility. Great possibilities to move to different sites inside the company.
cons: Sometimes to technology driven rather than consumer focused. Due to the flexibility of trying new roles people are sometimes not experts in their area (especially the more Marketing driven roles).

review_title: Overall, a good place to work at
pros:
You have the chance to learn and work on new technologies, which usually worth the effort, but  you wont be pushed to work really hard.
People and the environment are friendly. You can have your own opinion and ideas, to improve everyday work. Also have many perks to choose from and free time / sport activities.
cons: Just a few experts, so knowledge transfer and personal development is slow. Many managers, without the needed soft-skills to work with people or on projects. Usually no time for thorough planning and work, and have to apply quick fixes and workarounds, which wont work on the log run. People should take more responsibilities in general.

job_title: Member of Technical Stuff in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Colleagues are nice and helpful, and many of them are smart and excellent on their research.
cons: Too much effort on selling immature research to business units. Unbelievable amount of time is spent in presentation and demo preparations which end up to nothing all the time, and relative little in solving the actual problem at hand. Too many management layers compared to researchers actually get the job done. Poor management as you can notice a large amount of duplication of work across teams in Bell Labs as well as in R&D of Nokia due to lack of communication, or simply because different managers want a piece of the pie of the next Big Thing as mentioned in another review. Salary is not bad at start but not after two years as it is almost not increasing.

review_title: Excellent to progress and learn career-wise (up until about 1 year ago). Flexible. Very bad HR overall though.
pros:
Up until about a year ago it was a very good company to progress career wise and offered the possibility to move into different areas of work (logistics, sales) and so learn more about the complete picture of phone manufacturing.
Flexible hours.
cons:
Company is in transition and the change seems to be too slow and lack clear direction.
Still too much work is done in silos with conflict of interest between departments.
Nokia HR Spain (at least) shows no respect towards employees being laid off and it has a negative effect on current employees' motivation. Really makes you question if the Nokia values still exist.

review_title: Good secure place to work, but you won't get rich or grow career.
job_title: Engineering Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
MSFT bought Smart PHones division.  Even better stability.
Excellent work environment, with horizontal organization, good team attitude.
Vacation policy similar to Europe.
8% 401k matching
Very international diverse team.  many people from Asia and Europe.
OK pay.
Generally very competent engineers.
cons:
MSFT bought Smart PHones division. Do we all keep our jobs??
Big company processes.
San Diego office is plays a minor role. Many tech teams headed in FI or Bay Area
Pay is average compared to other top employers in area.
Shrink mode has caused limited career opportunities in San Diego.
Products struggle to gain market share.
Matrix organization provide mixed messages to employees and is confusing.
No offices.  All cubes.

review_title: Every third Thursday is a RIF in North America
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
-Our CEO and Chairman have a good vision and execute. 
-Networking products are market leading
-Good benefits
cons:
Since you are always fearful of a reduction in force, it causes real trust issues between the staff and management. The US has had nonstop RIF’s since 2014 and being a normal company doesn’t appear on the horizon.

Competitive salaries only applies to new hires, once you are in - don’t expect any increases. As a manager, I am given no budget to give increases —even to my best employees.

pros: Great work life balance, very strong opportunities to move around & up, trustworthy senior mgmt.... the company offers a balanced lifestyle & allows you immense flexibility in designing your work life.. most people are respectful and it is socially unnacceptable in Nokia to be a 'jerk'... career opportunities are plenty and there is scope to reinvent yourself every few years... The company is amazing non heirarchichal, still true to it's Scandinavian roots in that sense...In Nokia, I am in for the long haul...
cons: compensation needs more thought... the benefits are very good, but the actual pay is not competitive....

pros: technology leader (almost), friendly atmosphere. Respect for people's personal needs, managers try to match company's needs with employee's preferrences when assining jobs. Well equipped labs. Open relations with managers. Not much pressure, no micromanagenet. Good bennefit package, but salaries somewhat stalled in past few years. Equal treatment. Considerate and knowledgeable middle management.
cons:
A bit constrained tech-wise as there is (at least in Van) only one line of HW products, namely cell phones. In that sense, there is somewhat modest room for innovation and creativity. Sometimes slow to respond to market trends. 
Some mid-managers are technicaly competent, but sleezy and incapable of leading organizing a simple meeting, let alone a team.

review_title: Good place for work and life
job_title: Software Development Specialist in Chengdu, Sichuan
pros:
1. The best place (no "one of") for balance working and life in my current career. i really appreciate Nokia, in past years i worked in Nokia, I married, have one boy.   I can spend time in my family.  
2. Join global development, opportunity for getting new ideal, new software technology implementation.
3. Technical study group, join opensource project. Best information and practice in CI, Automation test(Robot framework is opensource by Nokia).
4. Working place is one good place, have good environment. it is far away from city but it is ok to me.
cons:
1. Slow technical upgrade, but i think it is because NOKIA is one communication company, So software focus on stability, compatibility. Good news is NOKIA is trying more faster in technology upgrade, but..need more i think.
2. big company disease.

review_title: Great place to work and grow
pros: It has a great culture, especially from the Nokia lineage. the company promotes people based on their performance, their eagerness to contribute to the organisation and their capabilities. NSN lays a lot of emphasis on learning and career councilling. The employee is free to choose the training courses he would like to attend to boost his domain knowledge/skills. At times, such trainings are also mandatory and therefore need to be taken on a mandatory basis. The employee is free to choose the training courses he would like to attend to boost his domain knowledge/skills. At times, such trainings are also mandatory and therefore need to be taken on a mandatory basis.
cons: none that i can think of

review_title: Good company, but needs improvement in compensation and communication
pros: Nokia offers the opportunities to interact with people from all over the world.  Interacting with multiple cultures broadens each of our own horizons and allows us to learn how different people perceive similar situations. Although there are new remote communication tools available, there is nothing more beneficial than a face-to-face meeting.
cons: Working with people from all over the world makes scheduling meetings somewhat challenging.  Salary increases are less than satisfactory since not even a cost of living increase is provided, which means we are taking a net reduction in pay.

review_title: Excellent company to learn and grow in.  Many opportunities if you are willing to give your energy and enthusiasm.
job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Nokia is profitable and has large cash reserves.  I found it a fantastic place to work and learn.  The scale of the operation is phenomenal - especially the software organisation.  I had no problem building a long career at Nokia. The benefits are very good - particularly compared to other US companies.
cons: Working for a US operation headquartered in Finland can be tough when corporate decisions seem to be too far removed from the reality of your local market.  Being large, this ship can be slow to turn - patience, persuasion and often travel to Finland are required to initiate important changes.

review_title: Could be great; but mired in overhead and a lack of direction
pros:
Great people
great access to devices
incredible potential
great spirit
may have incredible opportunities given early 2011 re-focus
cons:
Incredibly bureaucratic internal support groups and management
Has lacked leadership (in terms of inspiring and motivating) for too long
Poor internal communication tools, and a company that is in a large number of areas- both in terms of technology and geographies
Currently in turmoil

pros: Very few, internally.  Perhaps the best is the flexible benefits package that was brought over from the Alcatel-Lucent acquisition.  There was excellent location flexibility, but this is being slowly eroded.  Externally, a recognizable brand that opens doors, albeit for the wrong things [handsets, which Nokia doesn't make anymore].  There are opportunities to move abroad.
cons: This is a very strange company, that focuses on the wrong things.  Most senior management is of very questionable quality, with limited gravitas and ability to motivate.  The least inspiring management team I have ever seen.  This is a chaotic company, but one that thrives on processes and bureaucracy for their own sake - there are many people in back-office function that provide little value, whilst front line sales and marketing is continually cut.  Nokia's culture is passive aggressive and will attempt  to bully its employees to meet fictional, and often pointless, goals.  It is truly awful.

pros:
- Nice people
- Good place to build up some experience
cons:
- Red tape galore
- Constant re-orgs
- Extreme retention of dead wood
- Weak leadership and vision on services and software side
- General lack of accountability from upper management
- Acquisitions used as the major business strategy
- Poor integration of services and software
- Fighting and turf wars between sites and departments

pros: Since the company was big, you'd have a lot of flexibility, and proper processes and career paths in place.
cons:
Old-school performance review system means that there's a lot of "gaming", instead of people working towards a common goal. All in all, I tribute that to the downfall of Nokia, and their eventual sell-out to Microsoft.

If there had been more incentives for working together more across the whole company, and not just on your local project, they could have been spared always having A, B, C, D and E contingency plans in place, wasting money like a leaky sifter.

pros: Making proud that u work for a world's best handset maker.  Working with Finns were good.  They speak straight forward and honestly.  Also there is no politics inside the organization.  The values of the organization were very good.  The Respect and Trust shown among the employees are excellent. Even though the compensation was not excellent, these values kept me to stay in the organisation.
cons: Recent spinoff of Nokia Networks. Even though Nokia was known as a handset company, it had its Technology infrastructure division called NOkia networks, that were having about 24000 people.  Nokia Networks was no.2 Mobile Telecom Vender, but because of the industry changes, they have to spin off the Nokia Networks

review_title: Fair to employees, lack of focus
pros: Generous base pay, bonuses, benefits, opportunity to travel, opportunities to explore other fields within the company.  Everyone is treated with respect and allowed to voice his or her opinion freely.
cons: Direction from management is scattered; many groups are basically autonomous and left to their own devices.  There's heavy competition to be the best internal group in that specific space, so there's a tremendous amount of duplication in efforts and not enough meaningful collaboration.

review_title: A nice place to work and growth
pros: Flexibility, internal development through e-learnings, courses and OTJ trainnings. Very challenging projects, great amenities (modern office layouts), depending on the project and business area, home office is something very common (I usually take 3 days a week for HO). Flat structure, you have the possibility to talk with almost everyone even with the highest levels of managers / directors. Benefits includes flexilble woring tinem, d
cons: Restructuring since 2011 keeps you thinking when will be the end of the process, and if your position will be one of the "restructuring head count reduction". In some cases, and depending on your Line Manager, you could be with no project assignment, or rotating from project to project with little participation on each one, only for avoiding charge hours to "home base".

review_title: A pleasant and at the same time exciting place to be
pros: Some super smart people in the organization. Global impact and prestige in what you do. Very interesting projects going on in what is now the New Nokia. Room to grow and learn and a burgeoning engineering culture. Work-life balance is pretty good. There is crunch time, but it is an exception and not the rule, everyone makes sure you don't overwork to burnout.
cons: Lots of politics and turf wars, the company should be nimbler. Quite a few layers of mid-level management, not as flat as you might think, you can notice some managerial overhead. Compensation and perks could be better as well. I guess frugality is the norm. Last but not least, though there are really smart folks, mileage varies enormously among teams.

pros:
Work life balance
Lot of work from homes 
Casual dress allowed
No check on the entry and exit times (depends on manager who usually leave before time and arrive late)
cons:
Bad compensation. It's understandable if you have pros like above you should not expect much compensation. There is trade off everywhere.
Worst management I have ever seen or listened albeit this was my first and only company. Nokia is good but can be better if management and seniors are skilled and resourceful.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Murray Hill, NJ
pros: Used to be a market leader
cons:
What once used to be a great place to work has been in a constant downward spiral, being passed like a "bad penny" from AT&T to Lucent to Alcatel-Lucent and now to Nokia.  At one point they used to develop and train their people to being industry leaders.  Now all their market leadership comes from hiring in top notch talent from the outside only to let people go after a few years in favor of newer and younger faces.

(Note: Jeong Kim has not been president of Bell Labs for several years -- CEO job performance rating reflects opinion of current president, Marcus Weldon.)

job_title: Software Engineer in Athens, Athens, Attica
pros: Nokia's R&D in Athens is a very good place for a graduated student. (S)He will learn a lot of things into a cozy and friendly environment. The main pros is ability to have touch with a lot of people all over the world and learn from them. Moreover,  he will have the opportunity to come in touch with a lot of new technologies, and learn from them.
cons: Even though the team work and the environment is very good, there are not chances of further development of an engineers career. You will be stacked both in salaries and job advancements for a lot of years.  I will advice for a graduated student to have it as a beginning into his career, but after 2 years to move to a next challenging job in another company.

job_title: RF Design Engineer in Hangzhou, Zhejiang
pros: I'm feel relaxing during working time. Good atmosphere makes me love my job, especially for innovation.  Working load is average in my opinion, so that it's benefit for us to have a good balance for our family and job. Wok is our duty but life have a lot of things that we should do. Nokia gives us good working chance and good life to have. Thanks to Nokia.
cons: I want to do and learn more about my job. Wok load is very important for us and company. For us, we always don't want to have much more work load. But for company, a little more work load can increase product processing. I think Nokia should encourage and teach us to have good efficiency to have balance about work load, product processing and other things.

review_title: Nokia, a great place to work but it can be frustrating at times.
job_title: Business Development Director in Tampa, FL
pros: Nokia is clearly the market leader globally in mobile communications. Its move to transform into a services company is managemenst anticipation of the market. In many markets around the world it is the No 1 brand and market leader.
cons: Nokia is sometimes slow to respond to competitors, but when it does it quickly overtakes them. In the North American market where the mobile operators control the value chain and technology is fragmented, Nokia is not as strong as it is in other markets. A lot of the management positions are held by Finns or are based in Helsinki which limits career opportunities.

review_title: Nokia was a good place to work because of the balance that they provide between your work life and your personal life
pros:
1. Good work life balance
2. Senior management very open and receptive to ideas
3. Opportunity to grow within the organisation are good
cons:
1. Not much stress on professional development
2. Don't pay very well
3. Too process oriented and bureaucratic at times
4. Too many company reorganisations

pros:
* Management don't overwork people. If we can't make on deadline, then we cut off features
* Great benefits and salary compared to other tech companies
* Lots of intelligent people working in the company
* Great gym, carwash facility, and basketball / tennis / volleyball area
* Great bonus payout
cons:
* Company is in constant flux so expect to move cubicles every 3 months.
* Lack of talent doing the web area. They make Symbian programmers do php programming which results in poor output.
* Promotion can be hard to come by if you don't stick to your team for a long time.
* Most of the people seemed content on what they have. There's no feeling of innovation at all.
* Too much reorganization - senior management do not know what they want.

review_title: Great company, awesome to be on the front line of technology.
job_title: Head of Department in New Delhi
pros:
The people in the organisation are great to work with, they are creative, focused, interested and above all they enjoy their work.  

The organisation is open and communicative, from top down they know that information is best shared and a lot of effort is made to ensure staff are included at all levels.
cons: Product leaks.   A blight on the industry generally but there is nothing more disappointing than when something you have been working on is leaked early.   It's like reading the last page of a book before you've started it.

review_title: Great people, great expertiese, not very great attempts to implement agile...
job_title: Senior Systems Quality Engineer in Bristol, England
pros:
1. Lots of things that can be improved which translate into a lot of opportunities to perform far above average
2. Not bad compensation
3. There is a whole bunch of great people and connections you can find in Nokia
cons:
1. Company is not exactly good at noticing good performance unless it's super visible to management. E.g. hard to get better opportunities
2. Very often quality is a lower priority than feature work. So it's not exactly easy to do anything to make a great product.

pros:
-Good place to start a career.

-Good salary for recent graduates

-Good benefits (free lunch, free health insurance)

-Possibility of working from home

-Schedule flexibility

-Work time control prevents the overtime abuses that are common in other organizations

-No dress code

-Free parking

-Good location if you live in the Lisbon area and want to escape most of the traffic
cons:
-Great place to start a career, awful place to pursue a career.

-There is a general sense of dissatisfaction with career progress. The general target is to leave after 2/3 years.

-Working from home is frowned upon by coworkers 

-Work time control sometimes makes you feel like you are a prisioner at your workplace

-Overcrowded building

-Poor parking conditions

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Alfragide
pros: Flexible work schedule, respectful, professional environment. Very good benefits, including 32 vacation days. Very smart people here. Many opportunities to move within the company.
cons: Lots of jobs moving overseas. My salary has been static for 10 years. Raises are scarce, though sometimes there is a bonus. Very few opportunities to move up. There is a very flat hierarchy for technical jobs. Job security is a constant concern as Alcatel-Lucent has been reducing it's workforce in the US for many years, and now that Nokia has bought it out, the future is uncertain.

review_title: Good place for my career path development
pros:
I worked here more than 10 years, range different roles, company provides wide opportunity for your challenge, no any boundary limitation if you are active, and willing to take more responsibility, and this is good way help employee to develop career path. I think I benefit from this. Management team will encourage you try to different thing, and support you done it well.

Also, Nokia is work-life balance place, not like start up company 996 (come to office at 9 am, leave office at 9 pm, and work 6 days in one week).
cons: The base salary is a bit low compare other internet companies.

pros: Globally recognised as a leader in domain with good pay and benefits, and the ability to work virtually, although there is a shift in the company to bring employees back into regional offices.  There are many very talented people and a wide range of expertise working here.
cons: Constant/ongoing reorgs, realignments and monthly staff reductions, with very little promotion oppty from within, especially in Americas. Expectation to work all/ long hours, typically averaging 50-60 hrs per week or more. Days spent in meetings, work done afterwards or between meetings.

review_title: The company that used to make popular phones
pros:
- Friendly atmosphere
- Work/Life balance is good
- Flexible work hours
- Overall company culture is nice
- laptop, phone and a nice benefit package
cons:
- Salaries are less than they should be.
- Cost-cutting and travel bans so middle and upper management can travel all they want.
- Outsourced IT department
- some people get promoted based on time served with the company without contributing anything but yammer posts
- Powerpoint Engineering

job_title: Product Manager, Devices in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1) Great brand to be associated with... strong affinity with the brand among employees
2) Agile company and quick decision making
3) 'Open Door' culture.... accessible senior management
4) Go-To-Market specialists... great execution team
cons:
1) Almost all the employees are from non-telecom background... mostly from FMCG industry
2) Very inward looking... arrogant when it comes to acknowledging competition
3) Totally cut off from the telecom industry and ecosystem
4) Although not shown on surface, but definitely hierarchical work culture
5) Identified the next direction and paradigm of growth (Services)... but unable to steer in the direction

review_title: The company changed backwards from 1995 to 2010
pros:
New Technology - You can find exciting technology to work on
Leading edge -
Nice People - The people respect each other but when it comes to survival ..good luck
Good benefits - 401 matching, health and vacations are good
cons: Making change for the sake of change every 6 months. Nokia is trying to have the perfect staff so they go through changes (layoffs) every 6 - 12 months. It does not work, look at the stock performance. The lay people off and buy companies to gain ground in some techology. It is very risky to work for such comapny. If you don't work in Finland forget it.

pros:
- Felxible hours, you can organize your working time and time off
- Somehow competitive salary
- In the heart of the technology fight
- Truly global player
cons:
Nokia is a hardware company that comes from market domination during the ´90 and beginning of 2000 and is now set to a low market segment, where hardware plays a very secondary role. Elop set a new strategy, but:

- Thr machine is extremely slow to react
- Senior managers are unable to lead anywhere
- Political wars are the everyday standard, especially in Location and Commerce Unit
- Forget about career, the senior management does not leave any free space for people below
- Any decision takes ages to be implemented and will be reviewed constatly (there are projects with no product release at all after 3 years, but still existing!!)

job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Great location in Chicago, convenient to public transit
- The subject matter is really interesting and challenging
- Well-maintained workplace in Chicago, free Keurig coffee, free gym, etc. 
- A lot of bright, motivated colleagues
- Sale of Devices & Services rids us of unprofitable business units
- Generous paid time off for long-time staff
cons:
- Rapidly changing industry; the company is betting the farm on products that may or may not succeed
- Some key functions like HR Benefits are outsourced, and the providers are largely useless and unresponsive
- A lot of ambiguity in software architecture: groups have can do what they want, but things don't always work together"
- Incentive-bonus schemes have mostly been empty promises.

pros: Sense of family and appreciation in early years, then the awful years of worry and lay offs.
cons: Arrogance within the company - not listening to what customers wanted

pros: If you work hard and are actually competent, things should go well for you. Many think they are competent, but really are not. Pay is above average, but has gone down for newcomers. Work/life balance is good when not busy. Prepare for long stretches of long workdays.
cons: If you work in wireless, on network deployments, then you should know what to expect. You will work with a lot of pretenders, and those of us who are competent will always have to carry the weight of the slackers (usually employees). Advancement potential is very limited. There is no identifiable "culture" in the USA, in my opinion. Most just work hard to stay employed, while other ride their coattails.

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Roswell, GA
pros: Great, dedicated, caring colleagues.  Lots of very good, timely, state of the art training, just need to find the time to get it all done.   Great effort in working towards great Product Portfolio and Services Portfolio
cons: Very competative, company still trying to find and define its culture, very good communicated direction/coaching but still early in merger with ALU and is still trying to fine itself dealing with super large operators AT&T and Verizon.  The next 2 years will be critical in defining if this will be a great company.

review_title: Not Goot for less than 10Y Exp employee
pros:
they never fired any employee
you can plan retirement from this company
you can get good amount while joining
cons:
appraisal is least in the market
no appreciation for any work
you have to be the part of politics any how
you will be working under a person who is planning his retirement definitely
learning is least as compared to other product based company
donkeys and horses are same for them(only specific will get noticed)
no visibility and 1-1 with manager
fresher don't spoil your career by joining this organization

pros: good work environment , good communication ，good workmate
cons: Little, but do not care.

review_title: People are great, job is tedious and no room for promotion
pros: Co-workers and supervisors are all amazing and friendly.
cons: Upper management is disorganized and the job doesn't have any promotion opportunities. The hours stink, I took this job thinking it was a normal M-F but it is 24/7. My hours are awful as I work nights and as far as work load there are days when you are literally surfing YouTube for cat videos because there is nothing to do.  Feels like you are wasting your time and not living up to your potential but in a very tough economy a paycheck is a paycheck.

pros: Flat management structure and flexible working hours in a international environment and culture. Open minded and you are expected to make a difference, possibility to work abroad as the company has 40.000 employe spreed over the world. it is a good place to start after graduate as Nokia still get's allot young talent in which can give you the young spirit
cons: Times of austerity makes people development hard as all spending 's are being challenged, the business in the mobile world is in general not that fun anymore due to the many competitors in the marked. Not the most motivated place to work, as the last years has been tough on the economic site. Management are mostly very talented engineers that got management positions, which gives a lack of leadership in some areas

pros:
Very flexible, opportunities to evolve into new roles and functions easily. Good values and very human colleagues. Flexible / lack of structure.
One of the few companies in Belgium where an international role can be found.
cons:
Overall Bureaucratic and very Political spirit, and management style is very variable depending on the manager. Some can be very demanding and lack some human respect values. Due to the lack of structure, such managers can keep harming people for a long time.
Average worker age is relatively old for the industry.

pros:
It's a great place to start for a fresh graduate.
The workload is not too demanding, having spikes, but generally without too much effort needing to be invested.
People are nice and everybody takes coffee breaks as often as they wish, depending of course of workload.
cons:
The opportunities to grow within the company do not come with financial rewards. If you want to become a BO (Level 2 Support Engineer) from a FO (GNOC Level 1) you need to be expecting little to none salary increment, while the salary of a GNOC is already a small one (the extra hours and shift making it the key to having an above average payment).
Also, to be able to grow you generally need to be liked by the proper people.

pros: Great flexible working hours (based on your mgr). Vast technical know-how within, and information is open, e.g, you ask and you get an answer (sometime too many opinions as well) kind of way. Just a very friendly and open company.
cons: limited advancement opportunity within. Telecom/Industry segment  is shrinking. Mgt is trying to do "more with less" for years. Employee related benefits (medical, 401k, travel reimbursement,etc) is subpar.

job_title: Lead Ansible Programmer in Naperville, IL
pros: The customer is right. The employees do their best to make customers happy.e
cons:
The product mix has too many specialized features.
Sales should focus on selling standard systems, with fewer specialty feature configuration options.  Selling widgets will do everyone better and decrease costs.
The outsourced development needst They need to focus on

pros:
The leader in the telecom industry
Innovative designs
Good training opportunities
Opportunities to travel overseas
Opportunities to make real difference to product lifecycle
Strong participation in all major standardization bodies
Good cooperation from NSN for testing new technologies
cons:
It still remains a "Finnish" company
All of the major decision are still made in Helsinki
Emphasis on US market is minimal
Glass ceiling - most of major senior positions are given to Finnish folks
Needs to lead better - not only from technological, but from strategy perspective.
Needs better partnership and JV
Not-invented-Here syndrome sometimes shows up 
Too slow adopting new methodologies
Needs to be more aggressive in acquisition strategies
Needs to find the "next big thing"
Needs to improve internal knowledge sharing

job_title: Product Manager in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Nokia Siemens Networks is a global, multi national company with offices in countries around the world.  There are lots of opportunities to work in different areas, different cities, different countries.
cons: Historically driven on a financial performance quarter by quarter it has now shifted to half by half but that is still too short a period given the long sales cycles and long development cycles inherent in this industry.  Parent companies can sometimes appear impatient.

review_title: Nokia India R & D Center - a place full of low quality engineers
pros:
- Very good work-life balance (sometimes more towards the life side!)
- A good eco system integrated well into the head quarters (Finland)
cons:
- Rampant recruitment by lowering the quality bars at every level (from senior management to software engineers)
- I have worked with software engineers who could not write a 'for loop' properly at Nokia Bangalore; no idea how they got recruited 
- Poor leadership and management skills of middle level managers - who have been recruited from services companies and who's mindset has not changed from viewing the headquarters (Finland) as just a 'client' 
- Poor accountability due to frequent re-organizations

review_title: Rating Nokia as a Company to work for
job_title: Specialist and Global Process Owner in Bangalore
pros: Exceptional good work culture and work environment. Possiblity to learn and grow up in your career with Nokia. There has been always good appreciation and recognition for the good work by the employees. There would be good opportunity to meet people of different cultures, background and the exposure and experience you would gain from them is amazing.
cons: Strategies from the top management have gone wrong always. It has adversely affected the work force and work all around the world in Nokia. Decision to ramp down main OS, not to go for Andriod. picking up MS...seems like everything has gone wrong and nothing is working at the moment for the company. And due to these decisions day by day market share is also going down globally.

review_title: Nice company, but just too big and slow.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Farnborough, England
pros:
When I started the work environment was good, with a nice office, gym and active company sports and social clubs.
The company clearly values their employees, with regular opportunities to feedback and communicate to management at all levels (the CEO will even respond to direct emails).
cons:
Because of the size of the company it can be difficult to get things done, with everyone getting tied down with bureaucracy, which will frustrate most.  Constant pressure to deliver planned products doesn't leave any time to innovate, or try anything new, unless it's mandated from on high.
Lost a lot of technical expertise with recent mass redundancies, and I'm not sure how well they'll cope afterwards.

review_title: Nokia was a great place to work.
job_title: Material Program Manager in Irving, TX
pros:
- Ability to control your own destiny; lots of responsibility with equal authority
- Share in successes with good bonus plan
- Excellent internal communication on strategy
- Liberal vacation and time off policy
- Mobile/Global work force
- Well stated value system
- Took care of their employees very well in the decline
cons:
- Wrong strategic choices caused significant market share declines
- Endless layoffs lead to fragmented processes with unknown process owners
- Old management had their own vision of what mobile should be which didn't coincide with the trade customer's vision

review_title: Now becoming service based company, only focus on cost cutting and cheap labor
job_title: Systems Verification Engineer (R&D Engineer) in Bangalore
pros:
Pros: only if you are a Senior member (lead/manager or above)
: enjoy like picnic,
: work from home (no work at all so no need to be available)
: most of the facilities like home lease etc.

for engineers: not applicable
cons:
for engineers:
no life or facilities for engineers. focus is on cost cutting and cheap labor. no space for lunch, no work-space for freshers and they are siting in meeting rooms/cafe area, 4K employees sitting in the building having capacity of 3K. weekend work and late stay frequently. too much politics. no ethics or values. 

only if you are a Senior member (lead/manager or above)
Not applicable

review_title: Good company moving in the right direction
job_title: Customer Programmer Manager in Bristol, England
